habitat: Hoplitis ochraceicornis possibly occurs in Mediterranean-type shrublands, although the habitat has not been described. It nests in cavities in rocks and the cells are built from mud (Benoist 1931). The species is mesolectic, in that it collects pollen from several plant families, such as Echium (Boraginaceae), Fabaceae and Lamiaceae (Sedivy et al. 2013a).
population: The population size and trends of this species are not known although due to the species' wide distribution and solitary behaviour, it is presumed to have a large population.
range: Hoplitis ochraceicornis is endemic to southern Europe, from Portugal to Italy (Müller 2013).
useTrade: There is no current exploitation that could represent a threat to the species as a whole.
conservationActions: The species is not listed in any National Red Lists or Red Data Books. It is unknown whether it occurs within any protected areas. Further research should be conducted to determine the population size, trends and threats to the species.

habitat: The ecology of Hoplitis parnesica is currently unknown. This species possibly occurs in Mediterranean-type shrublands, although the habitat has not been described.
population: The population size and trends of this species are not known.
range: Hoplitis parnesica is endemic to Greece (Müller 2013).
useTrade: There is no current exploitation that could represent a threat to the species as a whole.
conservationActions: The species is not listed in any National Red Lists or Red Data Books. It is unknown whether it occurs within any protected areas. Further research should be conducted to determine the population size and trends, habitat and ecology, and threats to the species.

habitat:
This species occurs in temperate grasslands and in Mediterranean-type shrublands.

Hoplitis ravouxi nests in depressions or surface irregularities of stones, rocks or walls where the brood cells are more or less exposed, in small rock cavities where the cells are hidden. Nests contain two to eight cells. The brood cells and nest plug are made from pebbles cemented together with mud. Exposed cells are finally covered by a continuous layer of mud and small pebbles, in small stone or rock cavities. The orifice is closed with a layer of mud (Blüthgen 1920, Benoist 1931, Westrich 1989, Sedivy et al. 2013b). This species is mesolectic, in that the species prefers to forage upon several plant families, within the Fabaceae, Echium spp. (Boraginaceae) and Crassulaceae with a strong preference for Loteae (Benoist 1931, Westrich 1989, Gogala 1999, Banaszak and Romasenko 2001, Amiet et al. 2004, Sedivy et al. 2013a).
population: The population size and trends of this species are not known although due to the species' wide distribution and solitary behaviour, it is presumed to have a large population.
range: Hoplitis ravouxi is endemic to Europe and has a large distribution from Portugal to Russia in the east and from Italy to the Netherlands in the north (Scheuchl 1996, Banaszak and Romasenko 2001, Amiet et al. 2004).
useTrade: There is no current exploitation that could represent a threat to the species as a whole.
conservationActions: The species is listed in the National Red List of Germany (Endangered; Westrich et al. 2011). It is unknown whether it occurs within any protected areas. Further research should be conducted to determine the population size, trends and threats to the species.

habitat: This species possibly occurs in temperate grasslands and in Mediterranean-type shrublands, although the habitat has not been described. The ecology of Hoplitis tenuispina is currently unknown. The females possess a specialized pilosity on clypeus and frons composed of apically twisted bristles (unpublished data A. Müller pers. comm. 2014). Similar facial combs occur in several unrelated bee taxa where they serve to remove pollen from the nototribic anthers (the structures in the flower that allow for the collection of pollen from insects) of Lamiaceae and Antirrhineae flowers (Müller 1996b, Houston 2000, Thorp 2000). Therefore, the flowers of the Lamiaceae may be important pollen sources for this species.
population: The population size and trends of this species are not known.
range: Hoplitis tenuispina is endemic to France and Italy (Schwarz et al. 2005).
useTrade: There is no current exploitation that could represent a threat to the species as a whole.
conservationActions: The species is not listed in any National Red Lists or Red Data Books. It is unknown whether it occurs within any protected areas. Further research should be conducted to determine the population size and trends, habitat and ecology, and threats to the species.

habitat: Hoplitis tkalcuella possibly occurs in Mediterranean-type shrublands, although the habitat has not been described. It nests in excavated burrows in rather hard soil. The entrance burrow ramifies after a length of around one centimetre into four branches, each containing one to three linearly arranged cells separated from each other by a layer of mud. The cell partitions and nest plug are built from mud (Le Goff 2003c, 2010). This species is oligolectic, in that it prefers to forage upon a narrow range of flowering plant species, primarily on Echium (Boraginaceae) (Le Goff 2003c, unpublished data A. Müller pers. comm. 2014).
population: The population size and trends of this species are not known.
range: Hoplitis tkalcuella is endemic to Spain (Le Goff 2003c).
useTrade: There is no current exploitation that could represent a threat to the species as a whole.
conservationActions: The species is not listed in any National Red Lists or Red Data Books. It is unknown whether it occurs within any protected areas. Further research should be conducted to determine the population size, trends and threats to the species.

habitat: Hoplitis villosa possibly occurs in temperate grasslands, forests (or forest edges) and in Mediterranean-type shrublands. It nests in pre-existing cavities like fissures and holes in rocks, stones and cinder, between stones, in abandoned nests of Megachile parietina and between pieces of bark. The cells, which are built singly or in small groups, are entirely constructed from several layers of petals (Geranium, Helianthemum, Hieracium, Meconopsis, Rosa, Ranunculus, Papaver) cemented together with sand or mud in varying quantities; the extremes are pure petal cells on the one hand, and mud cells with petals only on the outside on the other hand (Friese 1923, Benoist 1931, Stoeckhert 1933, Petit 1970, Westrich 1989, Müller et al. 1997, Banaszak and Romasenko 2001). This species is oligolectic, in that it prefers to forage upon a narrow range of flowering plant species, and in this case upon Asteraceae with a preference for Cichorioideae (Westrich 1989, Banaszak and Romasenko 2001, Amiet et al. 2004).
population: The population size and trends of this species are not known although due to the species' wide distribution and solitary behaviour it is presumed to have a large population.
range: Hoplitis villosa is endemic in Europe and is widely distributed across Europe except in Great Britain (Scheuchl 1996, Banaszak and Romasenko 2001, Amiet et al. 2004).
useTrade: There is no current exploitation that could represent a threat to the species as a whole.
conservationActions: The species is listed in the National Red Lists or Red Data Books of the Czech Republic (Critically Endangered; Farkac et al. 2005) and Germany (Endangered; Westrich et al. 2011). It is unknown whether it occurs within any protected areas. Further research should be conducted to determine the population size, trends and threats to the species.

habitat: This species possibly occurs in Mediterranean-type shrublands, although the habitat has not been described. The ecology of Hoplitis zandeni is currently unknown. This species has been found on the following flowers: Launaea arborescens, Phagnalon spp., Heliotropium ramosissimum and Ononis spp. (Hohmann et al. 1993).
population: The population size and trends of this species are not known.
range: Hoplitis zandeni is endemic to the Canary Islands (Spain) (Teunissen and van Achterberg 1992).
useTrade: There is no current exploitation that could represent a threat to the species as a whole.
conservationActions: The species is not listed in any National Red Lists or Red Data Books. It is unknown whether it occurs within any protected areas. Further research should be conducted to determine the population size and trends, habitat and ecology, and threats to the species.

habitat: Osmia alticola possibly occurs in temperate grasslands and forests (or forest edges), although the habitat has not been described. It nests in excavated short burrows (six to seven centimetres deep) in the ground with one cell at the end. The cells are entirely built of chewed leaves. Fragments of rootlets are glued to the whole cell surface (Benoist 1922, 1931). This species is possibly oligolectic, in that it prefers to forage upon a narrow range of flowering plant species, and in this case upon Fabaceae (Amiet et al. 2004).
population: The population size and trends of this species are not known although due to the species' wide distribution and solitary behaviour, it is presumed to have a large population.
range: Osmia alticola is endemic to the mountains of southern Europe in Spain, France, Switzerland and Austria (Haeseler 1999, Amiet et al. 2004).
useTrade: There is no current exploitation that could represent a threat to the species as a whole.
conservationActions: The species is not listed in any National Red Lists or Red Data Books. It is unknown whether it occurs within any protected areas. Further research should be conducted to determine the habitat and if there are any threats to the species.

habitat: This species possibly occurs in Mediterranean-type shrublands, although the habitat has not been described. The ecology of Osmia ariadne is currently unknown.
population: There is no information available for the population size and trend for this species.
range: Osmia ariadne is endemic to Crete (Greece) (Müller 2013).
useTrade: There is no current exploitation that could represent a threat to the species as a whole.
conservationActions: The species is not listed in any National Red Lists or Red Data Books. It is unknown whether it occurs within any protected areas. Further research should be conducted to determine the population size and trends, habitat and ecology, and threats to the species.

habitat: Osmia balearica possibly occurs in Mediterranean-type shrublands, although the habitat has not been described. It nests in excavated burrows (three to five centimetres deep) in loose sandy ground with one cell at the end or with several cells constructed closely side by side. The burrows are often near dead plants whose roots serve to attach the cells in to the ground. The cells are entirely made of chewed leaves (e.g. from Lotus, Medicago, Convolvulus, Cistus and Ononis spp.) (Haeseler 2005, 2008). This species is probably oligolectic, in that it has a narrow preference for plant species, primarily on Fabaceae (Haeseler 2008).
population: The trend and population size of this species are not known.
range: Osmia balearica is endemic to Spain (mainland and Baleares) (Haeseler 2005, Müller 2013).
useTrade: There is no current exploitation that could represent a threat to the species as a whole.
conservationActions: The species is not listed in any of the National Red Lists or Red Data Books. It is unknown whether it occurs within any protected areas. Further research should be conducted to determine the population size, trends and threats to the species.

habitat: The ecology of Osmia dusmeti is currently unknown. This species possibly occurs in Mediterranean-type shrublands, although the habitat has not been described.
population: The trend and population size of this species are not known.
range: Osmia dusmeti is endemic to the Spanish mainland (Müller 2013).
useTrade: There is no current exploitation that could represent a threat to the species as a whole.
conservationActions: The species is not listed in any National Red Lists or Red Data Books. It is unknown whether it occurs within any protected areas. Further research should be conducted to determine the population size and trends, habitat and ecology, and threats to the species.

habitat: This species possibly occurs in Mediterranean-type shrublands, although the habitat has not been described. The nesting behaviour of Osmia iberica is currently unknown. This species is possibly polylectic, in that it prefers to forage upon a wide range of flowering plants species (unpublished data A. Müller pers. comm. 2014).
population: The trend and population size of this species are not known.
range: Osmia iberica is endemic to Spain and Portugal (Müller 2013).
useTrade: There is no current exploitation that could represent a threat to the species as a whole.
conservationActions: The species is not listed in any National Red Lists or Red Data Books. It is unknown whether it occurs within any protected areas. Further research should be conducted to determine the population size and trends, habitat and ecology, and threats to the species.

habitat: This species possibly occurs in Mediterranean-type shrublands, although the habitat has not been described. The ecology of Osmia larochei is currently unknown.
population: The trend and population size of this species are not known.
range: Osmia larochei is endemic to the Canary Islands (Tkalcu 2000a).
useTrade: There is no current exploitation that could represent a threat to the species as a whole.
conservationActions: The species is not listed in any National Red Lists or Red Data Books. It is unknown whether it occurs within any protected areas. Further research should be conducted to determine the population size and trends, habitat and ecology, and threats to the species.

habitat: This species possibly occurs in Mediterranean-type shrublands, although the habitat has not been described. The ecology of Osmia madeirensis is currently unknown.
population: The trend and population size of this species are not known.
range: Osmia madeirensis is endemic to island of Madeira (van der Zanden 1991b).
useTrade: There is no current exploitation that could represent a threat to the species as a whole.
conservationActions: The species is not listed in any National Red Lists or Red Data Books. It is unknown whether it occurs within any protected areas. Further research should be conducted to determine the population size and trends, habitat and ecology, and threats to the species.

habitat: This species possibly occurs in Mediterranean-type shrublands, although the habitat has not been described. The ecology of Osmia mirhiji is currently unknown.
population: The trend and population size of this species are not known.
range: Osmia mirhiji is endemic to Lesbos island in Greece (van der Zanden 1992b).
useTrade: There is no current exploitation that could represent a threat to the species as a whole.
conservationActions: The species is not listed in any National Red Lists or Red Data Books. It is unknown whether it occurs within any protected areas. Further research should be conducted to determine the population size and trends, habitat and ecology, and threats to the species.

habitat: This species possibly occurs in Mediterranean-type shrublands, although the habitat has not been described. The ecology of Osmia moreensis is currently unknown.
population: The trend and population size of this species are not known.
range: Osmia moreensis is endemic to Greece (Müller 2013).
useTrade: There is no current exploitation that could represent a threat to the species as a whole.
conservationActions: The species is not listed in any National Red Lists or Red Data Books. It is unknown whether it occurs within any protected areas. Further research should be conducted to determine the population size and trends, habitat and ecology, and threats to the species.

habitat: This species possibly occurs in Mediterranean-type shrublands, although the habitat has not been described. The ecology of Osmia palmae is currently unknown.
population: The trend and population size of this species are not known.
range: Osmia palmae is endemic to the Canary Islands, Spain (Tkalcu 2001).
useTrade: There is no current exploitation that could represent a threat to the species as a whole.
conservationActions: The species is not listed in any National Red Lists or Red Data Books. It is unknown whether it occurs within any protected areas. Further research should be conducted to determine the population size and trends, habitat and ecology, and threats to the species.

habitat: This species possibly occurs in Mediterranean-type shrublands, although the habitat has not been described. The nesting behaviour of Osmia picena is currently unknown. This species is oligolectic, in that it prefers to forage upon a narrow range of flowering plant species, specifically upon Asteraceae with a preference for Carduoideae (unpublished data, A. Müller pers. comm. 2014).
population: The trend and population size of this species are not known.
range: Osmia picena is endemic to Italy (Tkalcu 1999).
useTrade: There is no current exploitation that could represent a threat to the species as a whole.
conservationActions: The species is not listed in any National Red Lists or Red Data Books. It is unknown whether it occurs within any protected areas. Further research should be conducted to determine the population size and trends, habitat and ecology, and threats to the species.

habitat: Osmia pilicornis occurs in temperate grasslands and forests (or forest edges). It nests in insect burrows in dead wood. The nest cells are made of chewed leaves (e.g. of Fragaria spp.) (Amiet et al. 2004). This species is polylectic, in that it prefers to forage upon a wide range of flowering plant species, but with a preference for Pulmonaria spp. (Boraginaceae) (Westrich 1989, Müller 1995, Amiet et al. 2004). The females possess hooked bristles on the galeae of the proboscis which serve to extract pollen from the narrow-tubed flowers of Pulmonaria spp. (Müller 1995, Müller et al. 1997).
population: The population size and trends of this species are not known although  due to the species' wide distribution and solitary behaviour, it is  presumed to have a large population.
range: Osmia pilicornis is endemic to Europe and it mainly occurs in central and northern Europe (Scheuchl 1996, Banaszak and Romasenko 2001, Müller 2002, Amiet et al. 2004, Wu 2006).
useTrade: There is no current exploitation that could represent a threat to the species as a whole.
conservationActions: The species is listed in the National Red Lists or Red Data Books of the Czech Republic (Endangered; Farkac et al. 2005), Finland (Near Threatened; Rassi et al. 2010), Germany (threatened but level unknown; Westrich et al. 2011), Great Britain (Vulnerable; Shirt 1987) and Switzerland (Vulnerable; Amiet 1994). It is unknown whether it occurs within any protected areas. Further research should be conducted to determine the population size, trends, and threats to the species.

habitat: This species occurs in sub-alpine and alpine stony slopes and grasslands (Müller 2002). The nesting behaviour of Osmia steinmanni is currently unknown. This species is probably polylectic, in that it prefers to forage upon a wide range of flowering plants species, with a strong preference for Fabaceae (Amiet et al. 2004, Müller 2002).
population: The trend and population size of this species are not known.
range: Osmia Steinmanni is endemic to the Alps in Italy and Switzerland (Müller 2002, Amiet et al. 2004).
useTrade: There is no current exploitation that could represent a threat to the species as a whole.
conservationActions: The species is not listed in any National Red Lists or Red Data Books. It is unknown whether it occurs within any protected areas. Further research should be conducted to determine the population size and trends, habitat and ecology, and threats to the species.

habitat: This species possibly occurs in boreal grasslands and forests (or forest edges), although the habitat has not been described. Specimens of Osmia svenssoni have been found nesting on the underside of a flat stone (Nilsson 2009). The flower preferences of this species are unknown.
population: The trend and population size of this species are not known.
range: Osmia svenssoni is endemic to Finland and Sweden (Nilsson 2009).
useTrade: There is no current exploitation that could represent a threat to the species as a whole.
conservationActions: The species is not listed in any National Red Lists or Red Data Books. It is unknown whether it occurs within any protected areas. Further research should be conducted to determine the population size and trends, habitat and ecology, and threats to the species.

habitat: Protosmia asensioi possibly occurs in Mediterranean-type shrublands, although the habitat has not been described. It nests in bore holes in pithy stems. The cell partitions and nest plug are made of resin (Griswold 1985). The flower preferences of this species are unknown.
population: The trend and population size of this species are not known.
range: Protosmia asensioi is endemic to Spain and Portugal (van der Zanden 1994b).
useTrade: There is no current exploitation that could represent a threat to the species as a whole.
conservationActions: The species is not listed in any National Red Lists or Red Data Books. It is unknown whether it occurs within any protected areas. Further research should be conducted to determine the population size and trends, habitat and ecology, and threats to the species.

habitat: Protosmia capitata possibly occurs in Mediterranean-type shrublands, although the habitat has not been described. It nests in insect burrows in dead wood. This species is polylectic, in that it prefers to forage upon a wide range of flowering plants species (unpublished data, A. Müller pers. comm. 2014).
population: The trend and population size of this species are not known.
range: Protosmia capitata is endemic to Spain and Portugal (Müller 2013).
useTrade: There is no current exploitation that could represent a threat to the species as a whole.
conservationActions: The species is not listed in any National Red Lists or Red Data Books. It is unknown whether it occurs within any protected areas. Further research should be conducted to determine the population size and trends, habitat and ecology, and threats to the species.

habitat: This species possibly occurs in temperate grasslands, forests (or forest edges) and in Mediterranean-type shrublands, although the habitat has not been described. The nesting behaviour of Protosmia minutula is currently unknown. This species is polylectic, in that it prefers to forage upon a wide range of flowering plants species, with a preference for small-flowered Lamiaceae (e.g., Teucrium spp.) (Müller 1996b, unpublished data A. Müller pers. comm. 2014). Pollen-collecting females climb the filaments of the stamina of Teucrium montanum, the flowers of which lack an upper lip, until the head is beyond the uppermost anthers, by rapidly see-sawing the underside of the abdomen against the anthers, the bees then directly picks up the pollen into the abdominal scopa (Müller 1996b, Müller et al. 1997).
population: The trend and population size of this species are not known.
range: Protosmia minutula is endemic to central and southern Europe (Griswold and Parker 1987, van der Zanden 1994b, Amiet et al. 2004).
useTrade: There is no current exploitation that could represent a threat to the species as a whole.
conservationActions: The species is not listed in any National Red Lists or Red Data Books. It is unknown whether it occurs within any protected areas. Further research should be conducted to determine the population size, trends and threats to the species.

habitat: Bombus atratus is perhaps the only Neotropical bumble bee that exhibits a broad plasticity in nest site selection, ranging from cavities constructed below ground (Cameron and Jost 1998) to aerial nests built in trees (Dias 1960, Gonzalez et al. 2004). Gonzalez et al. (2004) observed that nests are constructed by cutting pieces of vegetation, but these have not been mound shaped and appeared to be modified from vegetation already covering them. Hines et al. (2007) found nests in more grassy substrates in secondary forest or disturbed areas, where construction and maintenance involved cutting vegetation on top of or around the nest with the mandibles and moving these pieces using the mandibles or a backwards directed sweeping behaviour of the mid and hind legs (Gonzalez et al. 2004). In Bombus (Fervidobombus) atratus, if the queen disappears or is removed from her colony, she is succeeded by a mated worker, the false queen, which produce both female and male offspring and maintains colony development until the reproductive phase when new queens are produced (Zucchi 1973, Silva-Matos and Garófalo 1995). Many B. atratus colonies persist for more than one year, and are considered to be perennial (Moure and Sakagami 1962, Taylor and Cameron 2003). In five highland colonies, up to 80 workers and 589 immatures were recorded (Gonzalez et al. 2004). The average developmental time from egg to adult is 29.6 days  (Gonzalez et al. 2004). Tropical lowland colonies of this taxon switch between polygynous and monogynous cycles (e.g., Moure and Sakagami 1962, Zucchi 1973, Cameron and Jost 1998).
population: Population trends for this species are not available.
range: The Neotropical bumblebee Bombus (Fervidobombus) atratus Franklin is widely distributed in South America ranging from warm, lowland tropical and subtropical areas to cold, high altitude ecosystems (e.g., Paramo) in the Andes up to 3,400 m asl. (Moure and Sakagami 1962, Lievano et al. 1991, Abrahamovich et al. 2004, Gonzalez et al. 2004), and found marginally in the piso montano ranging between 2,800 and 3,800 m asl. (Nates Parra 2006). Such broad geographical and altitudinal distribution suggests the ability to adapt to different pollen sources and environmental conditions. It is present in Argentina (Buenos Aires, Catamarca, Chaco, Cordoba, Corrientes, Entre Rios, Formosa, Jujuy, La Rioja, Neuquen, Mendoza, Misiones, Rio Negro, Salta, Santa Fe, Santiago del Estero and Tucuman), Uruguay (Artigas, Canelones, Colonia, Durazno, Florida, Maldonado, Montevideo, Paysandu, Rivera, San Jose and Tucuarembo), Brazil (Bahia, Espirito Santo, Goias, Mato Grosso, Mato Grosso do Sul, Minas Gerais, Parana, Rio de Janeiro, Rio Grande do Sul, Rondonia, Santa Catarina and Sao Paulo), Paraguay (Alto Parana, Caaguazu, Caazapa, Central, Concepcion, Cordillera, Guaira, Itapua, San Pedro and Villa Hayes), Panama (Chiriqui), Bolivia (El Beni, Cochabamba, La Paz and Santa Cruz), Peru (Cuzco and San Martin), Ecuador (Azuay and Guyanas), Venezuela (Carabobo, Distrito Capital and Merida) and Colombia (Antioquia, Bolivar, Boyaca, Cundinamarca, Distrito Capital, Magdalena, Narino, Quindio, Santander and Valle de Cauca) (Rasmussen 2003, Abramovich et al. 2004, Moure and Melo 2012).
useTrade: This species is currently commercially reared for crop pollination in Argentina.
conservationActions: No information is available about conservation measures in place. It is not known if the species is present in any protected areas.

habitat: Apparently this is a common species in the Alti-plano region of southern Peru and Bolivia. In Peru it has only been observed at close to 4,000 m asl, generally an altitude suitable for few bees. Agriculture at this altitude is often interspersed with natural vegetation but the bees seem to forage and thrive also within agricultural fields (Rasmussen pers. comm. 2012).
population: It is apparently common in suitable habitat (C. Rassmusen, pers. obs. from multiple localities and visits). However, there is no information on the current population trend or distribution.
range: The type locality for this species is Lara, Argentina. It has been recorded from northwestern Argentina, Bolivia and Peru. It is present in high altitudes between 2,740 and 4,279 m asl. (Abrahamovich et al., 2002). In Argentina, it has been reported from Tucuman (Chaqiavil, Cumbré; El Infiernillo, Tucuman and Laguna Chalaqui) and La Rioja (Cerro Fancratina, Cueva del Medina). In Bolivia, it is known from La Paz (Cholquiri and Laguna de Titicaca) and Pañido (Illimani and Potosi). In Peru, it was reported from Arequipa (Arequipa), Cajamarca (Camacari), Cuzco (Pumamarca), Junín (La Merced) and Puno (Lago Titacaca and Puno) (Milliron 1973, Rasmussen 2003).
useTrade: This species is not used.
conservationActions: Occurrence records should be compared with land-use and areas of conservation. It is not known whether populations are present within protected areas. There do not appear to be any species specific conservation measure in place.

habitat: Bombus bellicosus occupies open grassland biomes in southern Brazil, Argentina and Uruguay (Martins and Melo 2010). It was recorded visiting various plant species from circa 20 families of angiosperms (Bortoli and Laroca 1990, Schlindwein 1995). Therefore, this species, like most other bumble bees can be considered a generalist, or polylectic. Observations on a nest of B. bellicosus, found in Uruguay, were presented by Varela (1992a, b), who reported a wax layer covering the brood chamber. The production of this wax cover, probably an adaptation against low temperatures, characterize the nests of Bombus spp. from temperate regions and has not been observed in the other tropical species of Bombus (Thoracobombus) occurring in Brazil. In Paraná, B. bellicosus has been found in sympatry with B. atratus and B. morio, two species widely distributed in South America, from Venezuela and Colombia to southeastern Brazil, Uruguay and central Argentina (Abrahamovich et al. 2004). The association of B. bellicosus with a temperate climate is clear, and models suggest that a warming climate will lead to a continued retraction southwards  (Martins et al. 2015).
population: Little is known about the current populations of B. bellicosus. However, we can infer some information about them based on local surveys conducted in open grassland fields in Paraná, Brazil, in the early 1960s and 1980s. At the time of both of those surveys, Bombus bellicosus was one of the most abundant native species. Despite its abundance in the grassland fields of Paraná, it was sporadically collected in other areas, contrasting with other co-occurring bumblebees, like B. atratus (Moure and Sakagami 1962). However, little information is available about the status of this species throughout the remainder if its range. It is possible that it has experienced similar declines, but equally likely that populations may be stable. Further study is necessary to determine its current status.
range: The original distribution of this species ranges from northwestern Argentina, Uruguay up to 24°46’S, in the state of Paraná in Brazil, where it reached its northeastern limit (Milliron 1973, Abrahamovich et al. 2004, Martins et al 2015). This species occurs solely in open grassland vegetation (Moure & Sakagami 1962). Recent studies have shown that the species may be extirpated from the northeastern portion of its range in Brazil (Martins and Melo 2010). Models of future distribution under climate warming show a continued retraction southward to colder regions (Martins et al. 2015).
useTrade: This species is not used.
conservationActions: There are few conservation reserves in the region of occurrence of Bombus bellicosus and the areas covered with grass fields have almost disappeared. Except for two conservation units, which together possess about 8,500 ha covered with native grasslands, the little that remained of this vegetation in private properties is restricted to ravines and areas with exposed sandstone blocks. The species was not considered in the most recent red list of threatened Brazilian fauna (only stingless bees were evaluated) (MMA 2014).

habitat: It can be found in pine oak forest, and deciduous and evergreen tropical forest (Rezedowski 1978). Specimens from Chiapas, Mexico, Guatemala and Honduras were observed in January, February and July to December suggesting that the species is found throughout the year (Labougle 1990, Abrahamovich et al. 2004).
population:
Ecosur (El Colegio de la Frontera Sur) compiled a database of 26,211 bumblebee records to assess the status and extinction risk of the Mesoamerican Bombus sp. fauna. To our knowledge there are no recent studies of bumblebee decline in Mesoamerica, including Mexico and Central American countries. Our database consists of 12,210 records of what we consider historic data (1867-2004), obtained from insect collections in the Americas and Europe. The database also contains 14,001 recent bumble bee records (2005-2014), mainly obtained through collaborative sampling efforts conducted by the University San Carlos in Guatemala and El Colegio de la Frontera Sur in Mexico.

We evaluated B. brachycephalus’ spatial distribution over time across its Mesoamerican range using a measure of change in the extent of occurrence (EOO) and a measure of persistence (analytical methods described in Hatfield et al. 2014). We also assessed changes in the species’ relative abundance, which we consider to be an index of abundance relevant to the taxon, as specified by the IUCN Red List Categories and Criteria (IUCN 2012). For all calculations we divided the database into historical (1867-2004, N = 274) and current (2005-2014, N = 74) records. This time-frame was chosen to meet the IUCN criteria stipulation that species decline must have been observed over the longer of three generations or 10 years. Average decline for this species was calculated by averaging the change in abundance, persistence, and EOO. We used these measures of change between the recent and historic time periods to estimate the population trend that has occurred in the past 10 years, and applied that trend to IUCN Criteria. This analysis yielded the following results:

  • Current range size relative to historic range: 27.60%    
  • Persistence in current range relative to historic occupancy: 53.75%
  • Current relative abundance relative to historic values: 23.55%
  • Average decline: 65.03%
range: This taxon is distributed from the mountainous areas of central Mexico to northern and the highlands of Chiapas, Guatemala and Honduras in Central America. In Mexico it has been reported from Nayarit, Jalisco, Michoacán, Morelos, Puebla, Veracruz, San Luis Potosí, Guerrero, Oaxaca and Chiapas. In Guatemala, from the departments of Escuintla, Izabal, Guatemala, Chimaltenango, San Marcos, Zacapa, Zacatepequez and Chiquimula. In Honduras from Tegucigalpa, Monte Uyacu and Francisco Morazan. In El Salvador, it is known from the departments of Santa Ana and Chalatenango. Its altitudinal distribution ranges from 300 to 2,800 m asl.
useTrade: This species is not used.
conservationActions: There is a need to protect the native flora, for instance creating habitat along field margins to benefit bumble bees and other pollinators, and to protect the habitat for species nesting below ground. The proposed measures may include changes in agricultural practices to preserve the nests on the ground, controlled fire management practices and good stewardship and sustainable use of insecticides (Ayala et al. 1996).

habitat: In Argentina, Bombus brasiliesis is associated with two species of Solanacea: Datura sp. and Solanum sp. (Abrahamovich et al. 2001a). It may be associated to some degree with lowland forest, although this requires verification.
population: Bombus brasiliensis is one of the less abundant species of Argentina (Abrahamovich 2001a,b). No information is available about the species in other regions. There appears to be no information available on population trends or current distribution for this species.
range: Bombus brasiliensis is distributed from central and southern Brazil to southern Uruguay (Abramovich et al. 2004). It has been recorded from Argentina (Misiones), Brazil (Bahia, Espirito Santo, Goias, Mato Grosso, Mato Grosso do Sul, Minas Gerais, Parana, Rio de Janeiro, Santa Catarina and Sao Paulo), Paraguay (Alto Parana, Caaguazu, Centra, Cordillera, Guaira, Itapua, Paraguari and San Pedro), and Uruguay (Maldonado) (Abramovich et al. 2004, Moure and Melo 2012).
useTrade: This species is not used.
conservationActions: No information is available about conservation measures in place or needed. It is not known if the species is present in any protected areas.

habitat: Bionomic information about Bombus brevivillus is unknown (Garofalo 2005). There appears to be little recorded information about the habitats or ecology of this species.
population: No information is available about current population size, trends, or geographic distribution.
range: Bombus brevivillus is distributed from northern Guyana to northeastern and central Brazil, near sea level, Guyana and Venezuela (Abramovich and Diaz 2002, Abramovich et al. 2004 and Moure and Melo 2012). It has been reported for Colombia by Millirion 1973 although is not listed by Liebano-Leon et al., 1994 (Abrahmovich and Diaz, 2002). In Brazil, this species occurs in part of the Amazon, monopolizes the Brazilian Northeast, reaching beyond the limits of Bahia (Martins 1994), Itabapoana, between Espirito Santo and Rio de Janeiro (Moure and Melo 2012, Sakagami 1976). The distribution of this species extends over the “Caatinga” (Zanella 2000, 2003) and “Campos rupestres” (Silva-Pereira and Santos 2006). It is found from round sea level, although the upper altitudinal limit is not known.
useTrade: In northeastern Brazil B. brevivillus has potential as a pollinator of crops of greenhouses and in open areas (Imperatriz-Fonseca et al. 2006), although there is no known current commercial market for this species.
conservationActions: Research on its ecology and population size and trends is recommended. It is not known if this species is present in any protected areas.

habitat: This species is commonly seen in both the western Andean slopes and in the inter-Andean valleys, common both in natural riverine habitats and in agricultural fields. It is considered only slightly less common than B. funebris (Claus Rasmussen pers. comm. 2012). The available records show an activity between February to October, the males appearing in late May or early June (Milliron 1973).
population: It is considered to be common in suitable habitat (pers. obs. in the valleys of Lima, Peru, C. Rasmussen). However, there is no current information on the population trend or distribution for this species.
range: The type locality for this taxon is Marcapata in Cuzco, Peru. In Peru, it has been found in Cuzco (Cuzco, Tambomachay), Pasco (Pachacayo, Tapapoccocha, Rio Fortaleta), Ancash (Huaraz, Valle Llaca), Apurimac, Junin (Tarma), Lima (Matucana, San Mateo), Topococha, Wuenococha, Huancavelica and Huánuco (Milliron 1973, Rasmussen 2003). A record from Ecuador (Milliron 1973) may be in error and further surveys are needed. It has been recorded between 610 and 3,670 m. asl. (Abrahamovich et al. 2002).
useTrade: This species is not used.
conservationActions: It is not known if the species is present in any protected areas. Occurrence records should be compared with land-use and areas of conservation. There are no specific conservation measures in place.

habitat: The areas where this taxon have been recorded correspond to those formerly occupied by tropical forest and shrubland which are now now heavily degraded. However, there is no information published about its specific habitat requirements.
population:
Ecosur (El Colegio de la Frontera Sur) compiled a database of 26,211 bumblebee records to assess the status and extinction risk of the Mesoamerican Bombus species fauna. To our knowledge there are no recent studies of bumblebee decline in Mesoamerica, including Mexico and Central American countries. Our database consists of 12,210 records of what we consider historic data (1867-2004), obtained from insect collections in the Americas and Europe. The database also contains 14,001 recent bumble bee records (2005-2014), mainly obtained through collaborative sampling efforts conducted by the University San Carlos in Guatemala and El Colegio de la Frontera Sur in Mexico.

We evaluated spatial distribution of B. digressus over time across its Mesoamerican range using a measure of change in the EOO (see Figure 1 in the Supporting Information) and a measure of change in persistence (analytical methods described in Hatfield et al. 2014). We also assessed changes in the species’ relative abundance, which we consider to be an index of abundance relevant to the taxon, as specified by the IUCN Red List Categories and Criteria (IUCN 2012). For all calculations we divided the database into historical (1867-2004, N =59 ) and current (2005-2014, N=13) records. This time-frame was chosen to meet the IUCN criteria stipulation that species decline must have been observed over the longer of three generations or 10 years. Average decline for this species was calculated by averaging the change in abundance, persistence, and EOO. We used these measures of change between the recent and historic time periods to estimate the population trend that has occurred in the past 10 years, and applied that trend to IUCN Criteria. This analysis yielded the following results:
  • Current range size relative to historic range: 72.23%   
  • Persistence in current range relative to historic occupancy: 120.94%
  • Current relative abundance relative to historic values: 16.68%
  • Average decline: 30.05%
range: Bombus digressus is restricted to some localities in the highlands of Costa Rica, where it was recorded from the departments of Cartago, Heredia, San José, Limón and Puntarenas, and one record in Guatemala at the type locality in Volcan de Fuego in the department of Escuintla. However, no additional specimens have been reported in this site because volcanic activity makes it impossible to visit. Only 72 records are known for this species, which has a limited extent of occurrence (EOO), estimated at 1,558 km² (see Figure 1 in the Supplementary Material).
useTrade: There is no use of this species.
conservationActions: There is a need to protect the native flora, especially the flowering plants of ruderal vegetation and protect habitat for nesting below ground (Ayala et al. 1996). The type locality in Volcan de Fuego in Guatemala is in a protected area. In Costa Rica, the majority of the records are within the conservation area of Cordillera Volcanica Central, which includes the following parks: Parque Nacional Braulio Carrillo, Parque Nacional Volcan Poas, Parque nacional Volcán Irazu and Parque Nacional Volcan Turrialba.

habitat: The habitat of this species corresponds in part to the evergreen tropical forest and the pine (Pinus) and oak (Quercus) forest (Rzedowski 1978), likely more abundant in the latter.
population:
Ecosur (El Colegio de la Frontera Sur) compiled a database of 26,211 bumblebee records to assess the status and extinction risk of the Mesoamerican Bombus sp. fauna. To our knowledge there are no recent studies of bumblebee decline in Mesoamerica, including Mexico and Central American countries. Our database consists of 12,210 records of what we consider historic data (1867-2004), obtained from insect collections in the Americas and Europe. The database also contains 14,001 recent bumble bee records (2005-2014), mainly obtained through collaborative sampling efforts conducted by the University San Carlos in Guatemala and El Colegio de la Frontera Sur in Mexico.

We evaluated B. diligens’ spatial distribution over time across its Mesoamerican range using a measure of change in the extent of occurrence (EOO) and a measure of change in persistence (analytical methods described in Hatfield et al. 2014). We also assessed changes in the species’ relative abundance, which we consider to be an index of abundance relevant to the taxon, as specified by the IUCN Red List Categories and Criteria (IUCN 2012). For all calculations we divided the database into historical (1867-2004, N =515 ) and current (2005-2014, N=304) records. This time-frame was chosen to meet the IUCN criteria stipulation that species decline must have been observed over the longer of three generations or 10 years. Average decline for this species was calculated by averaging the change in abundance, persistence, and EOO. We used these measures of change between the recent and historic time periods to estimate the population trend that has occurred in the past 10 years, and applied that trend to IUCN Criteria. This analysis yielded the following results:

  • Current range size relative to historic range: 69.44%    
  • Persistence in current range relative to historic occupancy: 93.83%
  • Current relative abundance relative to historic values: 44.68%
  • Average decline: 30.68%
range: The taxon is found from Northern México to Oaxaca. It occurs along the Sierra Madre Occidental (Sinaloa and Nayarit), the Eje Volcánico Transversal, the Sierra Madre Oriental (Veracruz, San Luis Potosí, Puebla, Hidalgo) and the Sierra Madre del Sur (Guerrero and Oaxaca). The altitudinal distribution ranges from 1,400 to 2,500 m for the Pacific and central portions of México (Sinaloa to Morelos), from 1,000 to 2,000 m in the Gulf side (Puebla, Veracruz, San Luis Potosí), and from 1,800 to 2,400 m asl in the Sierra Madre del Sur (Guerrero and Oaxaca). Its extent of occurrence (EOO), estimated with 819 records from a data set compiled by Ecosur, is 133,841 km².
useTrade: There is no use of this species.
conservationActions: There is a need to protect the native flora, especially the flowering plants of ruderal vegetation, to protect habitat for nesting below ground. The measures may include changes in agricultural practices to preserve the nests on the ground, controlled practice fire management and good stewardship and sustainable insecticides (Ayala et al. 1996). There do not appear to be any records from protected areas to date.

habitat: This bee has been caught in forested areas, never from open fields or near agriculture. It might need natural Andean forests and is presumed this would be one of the more susceptible species to habitat degradation nearby. Its distribution is similar to B. handirschi but possibly extends wider and visiting paramo like vegetation (Rasmussen pers. comm. 2012).
population: The species is considered to be naturally rare and there is no information available on the current population trend for this species.
range: According to Milliron (1973), its distribution is restricted to Ecuador and Peru, possibly also occurring in Bolivia. In Ecuador, specimens have been recorded in Bolivar (Balzapamba), Los Rios (Huigra) and Esmeraldas (Rio Bogota). Rasmussen (2003) reported this species from Peru in the departments of Apurimac, Ayacucho, Cusco, Huanuco and Piura. It has been recorded between 1,220 and 3,050 m. asl. (Abrahamovich et al. 2002).
useTrade: This species is not used.
conservationActions: It is not known if the species is present within any protected areas. Occurrence records should be compared with land-use and areas of conservation. There are no specific conservation measures in place.

habitat: This species is polylectic and will feed on a variety of floral sources. They can be collected throughout the year at mid to high elevation in pine-oak forest and moist montane forest habitats. They also pollinate a variety of crops and are used for greenhouse pollination of tomato and eggplant.
population:
There are no previous studies of bumblebee decline in the Mesoamerican region (Mexico and Central America). A database of all 26,126 bumblebee records of the region was compiled by Ecosur (El Colegio de la Frontera Sur). The historic data (1867-2004), obtained from insect collections in Americas and Europe, includes 12,210 records, while the recent data (2005-2014), mainly obtained through samplings by University San Carlos in Guatemala and El Colegio de la Frontera Sur in Mexico, includes 13,916 Bombus spp. records.

We evaluated the spatial distribution of Bombus ephippiatus over time across its Mesoamerican range using a measure of change in the extent of occurrence (EOO) and a measure of change in persistence (analytical methods described in Hatfield et al. 2014). We also examined this species’ difference in relative abundance from historical to current time periods (analytical methods described in Hatfield et al. 2014). The mean difference between EOO, persistence and relative abundance was used to estimate an average decline (any species with an average increase from historic to current time periods is reported as 0%). For all calculations we divided the database into historical (1879-2004, N = 4927) and current (2005-2014, N = 8396) records. This timeframe was chosen to meet the IUCN criteria stipulation that species decline must have been observed over the longer of three generations or 10 years. We used these measures of change between the recent and historic time periods to estimate the population trend that has occurred in the past 10 years, and to inform the application of an IUCN category. This analysis yielded the following results:

  • Current range size relative to historic range: 74.02%    
  • Persistence in current range relative to historic occupancy: 199.96%
  • Current relative abundance relative to historic values: 148.61%
  • Average decline: 0%
range: Bombus ephippiatus is known from the following countries and departments: Mexico: Chiapas, Chihuahua, Colima, Durango, Federal District, Guanajuato, Guerrero, Hidalgo, Jalisco, State of México, Michoacán, Morelos, Nayarit, Nuevo Leon, Oaxaca, Puebla, Queretaro, San Luis Potosi, Sinaloa, Tabasco, Tamaulipas, Tlaxcala, Veracruz and Zacatecas; Guatemala: Alta Verapaz, Baja Verapaz, Chimaltenango, Chiqué, Escuitla, Guatemala, Huehuetenango, Quetzaltenango, Quiché, Sacatepéquez, San Marcos, Sololá and Totonicapán; El Salvador: Ahuachapán, La Libertad and Morazán; Honduras: Comayagua, Francisco Morazán and Santa Barbara; Nicaragua: Jinotega; Costa Rica: Alajuela, Cartago, Guanacaste, Heredia, Irazú, Puerto Limón, Puntarenas and San José; Panama: Chiriquí (Duennes et al. 2012, Abrahamovich et al. 2004, Labougle 1990). This species can currently be found at altitudes from 0-3595 m and is the most commonly encountered bumblebee from Mexico through Honduras.
useTrade: This species is bred commercially for greenhouse crop pollination in Mexico. Because this species is still under development as a commodity, queens are regularly harvested from the wild for production of commercially available colonies.
conservationActions:
It is not known if this species is present in protected areas. No species-specific conservation measures are in place. 

This species is currently being collected and bred commercially for greenhouse crop pollination in Mexico. While Bombus ephippiatus is being designated as “Least Concern” for the IUCN Red List, it should be noted that this species is of increasing economic importance and its inter-regional movement for commercial pollination poses a threat to current patterns of genetic diversity. Unpublished research by Duennes et al. has revealed significant genetic structuring of sub-populations of this species. Unique genotypes exist in the Sierra Madre Oriental, Sierra Madre Occidental, the Trans-Mexican Volcanic Belt and the Sierra Madre del Sur. In order to preserve the current genetic diversity within this species, we advise bombiculture companies to keep the movement of B. ephippiatus colonies for pollination within these mountain ranges and not move sub-populations between mountain ranges.

habitat: The material available for this taxon is limited. The few records indicate that the flight activity extends from the second half of April to January, the males appearing as early as (probably late) May. It is found in Bolivia, northward at the higher altitudes to Venezuela. In Colombia, the species prefers very humid mesothermic areas of Andean forest (Liévano y Ospina 1984). It has also been recorded from perturbed land (Nates Parra 2006). In Peru it is considered the rarest of the Bombus species (Rasmussen pers. comm. 2012), where it has been recorded visiting Begonia and Citrus sinensis (Rutaceae) flowers (Rasmussen 2003, Milliron 1973a). The natural habitat is humid tropical premontane forests on the eastern foothills of the Andes, an interesting area characterized by high precipitation and cloud persistence unlike that habitat of most other Bombus species.  The habitat also forms a transition zone between the higher montane forests and the Amazonian lowland forests. It is noted that the few records of this species from Peru have been from agricultural fields, thus, it is apparently not a narrow habitat specialist (Rasmussen pers. comm. 2012).
population: This species is considered rare in Colombia because its presence in collections is very scarce (Nates Parra 2006) and very rare in Peru (Rasmussen 2003). No additional information is known for Bolivia Peru, Ecuador and Venezuela. There appears to be no information on current population trends.
range: The type locality is in Venezuela (Milliron 1973). In Ecuador, it has been recorded from Limón (unknown locality). In Bolivia, it is known in Cauca (Popayan), La Paz (Yungas del Palmar and El Palmar) and Cochabamba. In Peru, it was reported in Piura (Tambo), Puno (Valle Chanchamayo), Pasco and Junin (Rasmussen 2003). In Venezuela, it is known from Falcon, Bolivar, La Vega, Merida (unknown locality), Distrito Federal (Pico de Naiguata and Uguas Negras). In Colombia, specimens have been recorded in Caqueta (La Cumbre), Cauca (Popayan and Tasse), Magdalena (Vista Nieve, San Lorenzo Montes and Santa Maria) (Milliron 1973a). Its altitudinal range extends from 900 to 3,500 m. asl. (Rasmussen 2003).
useTrade: This species is not used.
conservationActions: It is not known if the species is present in any protected areas. Occurrence records should be compared with land-use and areas of conservation. There are no specific conservation measures in place.

habitat:
Bumblebees, as a whole, are eusocial insects that live in colonies composed of a queen, workers, and reproductives (males and new queens). Colonies are annual and only the new, mated queens overwinter. These queens emerge from hibernation in the early spring and immediately start foraging for pollen and nectar and begin to search for a nest site. Nests are often located underground in abandoned rodent nests, or above ground in tufts of grass, old bird nests, rock piles, or cavities in dead trees. Initially, the queen does all of the foraging and care for the colony until the first workers emerge and assist with these duties. Bumblebees collect both nectar and pollen of the plants that they pollinate. In general, bumblebees forage from a diversity of plants, although bumblebee species in a given area can vary greatly in their plant preferences, largely due to differences in tongue length. Bumblebees are well-known to engage in “buzz pollination,” a very effective foraging technique in which they sonicate the flowers to vibrate the pollen loose from the anthers.

Bombus fervidus is a long-tongued, later emerging species (Williams et al. 2014). It is found in open farmland and fields, urban parks, and gardens throughout its range and nests mostly on the surface of the ground, among long grass or in deserted mouse nests, but does occasionally nest underground.(Williams et al. 2014). This is one of the more aggressive bumblebee species, probably as an adaptation to protect more exposed above-ground nests (Williams et al. 2014).  Males congregate outside nest entrances in search of mates (Williams et al. 2014). Example food plants include Astragalus, Cirsium, Helianthus, Lonicera, Lythrum, Monarda, Pedicularis, Penstemon, Trifolium, and Vicia (Williams et al. 2014).  This species is a known host to Bombus insularis; it is probably also host to B. suckleyi (Williams et al. 2014).
population:
This species is synonymous with B. californicus, based on the lack of differentiation in DNA barcodes between individuals with this colour pattern and those with the B. fervidus s. str. colour pattern (Williams et al. 2014). The Mexican samples of this species are different from the US/Canada ones both morphologically (colour pattern of B. f. sonomae) and genetically (according to a preliminary DNA barcodes analysis), but further sampling is required to clarify their taxonomic status.

A number of published studies have demonstrated abundance and persistence declines in this species. A regional study of bumblebee community structure in Black Rock Forest, New York during the summer of 2003 found the current bumblebee community composition differed when compared to historical records; most notably, this survey of over 1,200 bumblebees failed to find B. affinis, B. pensylvanicus and B. fervidus despite their being noted as previously common in central New York (Giles and Ascher 2006). In another regional study in southern Ontario, Colla and Packer (2008) found B. fervidus (among others) had significantly and dramatically lower relative abundance in 2004-2006 than was exhibited during surveys at the same sites a few decades earlier (1971-1973). A larger study, considering over 69,000 bumblebee specimens of 21 eastern North America species collected from 1865-2010, assessed changes in relative abundance and occupancy of each species and ranked their conservation status throughout their entire United States and Canadian ranges (Colla et al. 2012). While most of the declining species exhibited declines between the last two time periods considered in the study, B. fervidus was found to be in chronic decline from earlier time periods to the present (Colla et al. 2012). Considering museum collections from the mid-1800s, this species was found to have declined by 70% in relative abundance since the 1930s (Colla et al. 2012).

We evaluated this species’ spatial distribution in North America (north of Mexico) over time using a measure of change in the extent of occurrence (EOO) and a measure of change in persistence (analytical methods described in Hatfield et al. 2014) (see Figure 1 in the Supplementary Material) . We also assessed changes in the species’ relative abundance (see Figure 2 in the Supplementary Material), which we consider to be an index of abundance relevant to the taxon, as specified by the IUCN Red List Categories and Criteria (IUCN 2012). For all three calculations we divided the database into historical (1805-2001, N=128,572) and current (2002-2012, N=74,682) records. This time frame was chosen to meet the IUCN criteria stipulation that species decline must have been observed over the longer of three generations or 10 years. Average decline for this species was calculated by averaging the change in abundance, persistence, and EOO. This analysis yielded the following results (see Supplementary Material for map of change in EOO over time (Figure 1) and graph of change in relative abundance (Figure 2)):

  • Current range size relative to historic range: 84.06%
  • Persistence in current range relative to historic occupancy: 85.84%
  • Current relative abundance relative to historic values: 38.04%
  • Average decline: 30.69%

This analysis suggests this species has suffered long term, steady decline. If this species' relative abundance continues to decline at the same rate, we project that it will reach zero in the next 70 to 80 years. The most recent time period shows the lowest relative abundance of all time periods. The relative abundance decline in the past decade has been nearly 50% from the mean. Note that this analysis includes records for B. californicus (a synonym of this species).

Mexican summary: The ECOSUR database (2015) includes 160 recent (2012-2014) records of this species from numerous Mexican states (Baja California, Chihuahua, Coahuila, Distrito Federal, Durango, Guanajuato, Hidalgo, México, Michoacán, Nuevo León, Puebla, Tlaxcala and Zacatecas).
range: This is a widespread species across much of the mid-latitudes of the continent, from the Canadian Maritimes and eastern United States in the Eastern Temperate Forest and Boreal Forest regions, west through the central Great Plains of the United States and southern Canada to the Mountain West, Pacific Coast and Western Desert of California. This species is not abundant in the Boreal region. This species is also present in Mexico, where it is known from the following states: Baja California, Chihuahua, Coahuila, Distrito Federal, Durango, Guanajuato, Hidalgo, México, Michoacán, Nuevo León, Puebla, Tlaxcala and Zacatecas (ECOSUR database 2015).
conservationActions:
Conservation Needs: 

  • Restoration, creation and preservation of natural grassland habitats.
  • Restriction of harmful pesticide use on or near suitable habitat.
  • Promotion of farming practices that increase the abundance of nitrogen-fixing fallow (legumes).
  • Protection of species from diseases introduced by managed bees.

With the exception of the above, specific conservation and research needs for this species have not been identified. Research needs for North American bumblebees (as a whole) are summarized in Cameron et al. (2011), the final report for the 2010 North American Bumble Bee Species Conservation Planning Workshop.


More detailed information on the population trends and status of this species in Mexico is needed.

habitat: This is a very common species both on the western Andean slopes and in all inter-Andean valleys. It appears to be less common at alti-plano (above 3,800 m asl.) and not found in Andean forests (Rasmussen pers. comm. 2012).
population: This species is common in suitable habitat. There is little information about the population trends for this species, but given its presence in field studies, observations, and collections it is likely stable, or at least common enough to be considered Least Concern.
range: The type locality for B. funebris is near Quito, Ecuador (Milliron 1973). It has been recorded from Chile, Bolivia, Colombia, Ecuador and Peru. In Colombia, specimens have been recorded from Nariño (Pasto and Volcán Galeras), Cundinamarca (Bogotá, Buenaventura, Guasca and Guerrero), and Obonuco. In this country, it was found on the montane floor, between 2,800 and above 3,800 m asl., reaching the permanent snow threshold at the National Natural Park of Los Nevado (Nates Parra 2006). In Ecuador, it has been reported from Loja (Yunguilla), Pichincha (Cotocallao and Quito), Tungurahua (Ambato and Mount Tungurahua), Pundoa, Azuay (Cuenca), Guayas (Guayagil) and Los Ríos (Limón). In Perú, was recorded from Ancash (Huaraz and Pillahuata), Arquetipa (Arquetipa and Cotahuasi), Ayacucho (Ayacucho and Huata), Cajamarca (Chimo, Cajamarca, La Huerta, Callanga and Tambomachay), Cusco  (Cusco and Urubamba), Junin (Acobamba, Huancayo, Pachacayo, Ocobamba and Tarma), Piura (Pilco), Puno, Lima (Canta, Matucana and San Mateo), Hucarua, Amazonas, Apurimac, Huancavelica, Huanuco, La Libertad, Tacna and Camacani (department indeterminate). In Bolivia, was reported in La Paz (Chulumani, Yungas de La Paz and Mapiri), Cochabamba (Tarata). In Chile, it is known from Coquimbo (Las Vacas) (Toro Gutiérrez 1986, Milliron 1973, Rasmussen 2003). Its altitudinal range goes from 610 to 3,810 m. asl. (Abrahamovich et al. 2002).
useTrade: This species is not used.
conservationActions: It is not known if this species occurs in any protected areas. Occurrence records should be compared with land-use and areas of conservation. No species specific conservation measures are in place.

habitat: Apparently the males don't appear until late January. It is likely that this species is generally found from early December to early February. There are no recorded plant associations for this species (Milliron 1973). This bee has been caught in forested areas, never from open fields or near agriculture. It might need natural Andean forests and is presumed this would be one of the more susceptible species to habitat degradation nearby (Claus Rasmussen pers. obs.).
population: While this species is currently common in montane forests throughout its range (C. Rasmussen pers. obs.), its habitat is under pressure from agricultural and other development. However, recent trends of its population are currently unavailable. Efforts to document this species' presence throughout its historic range would contribute greatly to our understanding of this species conservation status.
range: The type locality for this taxon is Marcapata in Cusco, Peru. It has been recorded from  Bolivia, Peru, Ecuador and Venezuela. In Peru, it was recorded from Ayacucho, Cuzco (Llutuyoe, Machu-Picchu and Marcapata), Huanuco, Amazonas (Pilca), Junin (San Miguel), Puno (Callanga) and Yanamonte. In Venezuela, it has been found in Territorio de Amazonas. In Bolivia, specimens have been reported from La Paz (Tarata and Yunga de La Paz). In Ecuador, a worker was reported from an unknown locality (Milliron 1973, Rasmussen 2003). It ranges between 1,830 and 3,050 m asl. (Abrahamovich et al. 2002).
useTrade: This species is not used.
conservationActions: It is mostly recorded from protected areas and forest (Rasmussen pers. comm. 2012). Occurrence records should be compared with land-use and areas of conservation. There are no species specific conservation measures in place.

habitat: This bumblebee is associated with mountains in Mexico (Abrahamovich, Díaz & Morrone 2004). It is probably affected by degradation and change of use of the land in its natural habitat.
population:
Ecosur (El Colegio de la Frontera Sur) compiled a database of 26,126 bumblebee records to assess the status and extinction risk of the Mesoamerican Bombus sp. fauna. To our knowledge there are no recent studies of bumblebee decline in Mesoamerica, including Mexico and Central American countries. Our database consists of 12,210 records of what we consider historic data (1867-2004), obtained from insect collections in the Americas and Europe. The database also contains 13,916 recent bumblebee records (2005-2014), mainly obtained through collaborative sampling efforts conducted by the University San Carlos in Guatemala and El Colegio de la Frontera Sur in Mexico.

We evaluated the spatial distribution of B. haueri over time across its Mesoamerican range using a measure of change in the extent of occurrence (EOO) and persistence (analytical methods described in Hatfield et al. 2014). We also assessed changes in the species’ relative abundance, which we consider to be an index of abundance relevant to the taxon, as specified by the IUCN Red List Categories and Criteria (IUCN 2012). For both calculations we divided the database into historical (1867-2004, N =70) and current (2005-2014, N=23) records. This time-frame was chosen to meet the IUCN criteria stipulation that species decline must have been observed over the longer of three generations or 10 years. We used these measures of change between the recent and historic time periods to estimate the population trend that has occurred in the past 10 years, and applied that trend to IUCN Criteria. This analysis yielded the following results:

  • Current range size relative to historic range: 9.74%    
  • Persistence in current range relative to historic occupancy: 40.31%
  • Current relative abundance relative to historic values: 27.86%
  • Average decline: 74.03%
range:
Historically, this species was distributed in Northern and Central Mexico (Aguascalientes, Coahuila, Chihuahua, Distrito Federal, Durango, México, Guanajuato, Jalisco, Michoacán, Morelos and Nuevo León (Labougle 1990), plus unpublished records from Guanajuato, Puebla. Additionally, there were supposedly three records from Honduras, based on specimens held at the Entomology Research Museum, University of California at Riverside, CA, USA but after checking those specimens they are definitely B. brachycephalus males.

However, it was not seen in its range for 22 years (since 1991 to 2013) and it has only been collected in Mexico State and Durango (Ecosur sampling effort).
conservationActions: The development and implementation of management plans for conservation and restoration of habitats for this species should be highly encouraged. There is a need to research the population genetics, and population ecology of this species to further evaluate extinction risk. This research should be used to develop comprehensive conservation plans, including habitat restoration, and protection from further degradation. In particular, areas that are known to be inhabited by this species from recent search efforts should develop education and outreach programs to protect remaining populations.

habitat: Specimens have been recorded from shrubland habitat. It seems to be recorded (queens, workers or males, or combination thereof) throughout the year at the appropriate place in the range of this species.
population: This species appears to be naturally rare. There is no information available about population trends, or current distribution.
range: According to Milliron (1973), the type locality for this species is Baños, Ecuador, and its distribution ranges from Ecuador northward through Colombia into Venezuela. Its altitudinal range goes from 760 to 3,800 m. asl. (Abrahamovich et al. 2002), the highest altitudes found in piso montano in Colombia (Nates Parra 2006). In Colombia, it has been recorded from Cundinamarca (Bogota, El Chico, Cota and Manjuy), Bolivar (Monte Redondo), and Magdalena (Onaca and Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta). In Ecuador, specimens are known from Guayas (Guayaquil), Oriente (Santa Rosa, Baños) and Tungurahua (Ambato and Mount Tungurahua). In Venezuela, one specimen was reported in Merida (El Escorial) (Milliron 1973).
useTrade: This species is not used.
conservationActions: It is not known from any protected areas in Peru. There is a need to compare occurrence records with land-use and areas of conservation. There are no specific conservation measures in place.

habitat:
Bombus huntii inhabits high desert scrub habitat, as well as prairies and meadows in the northern parts of its range. The distribution of this species in Mexico corresponds with pine vegetation (Labougle 1990). Example food plants of this medium-tongued species include Chrysothamnus, Cirsium, Ericameria, Helianthus, Medicago, Melilotus, Penstemon, Phacelia, Ribes, Rudbeckia and Trifolium. Nests are underground. Males patrol circuits in search of mates (Williams et al. 2014). In Mexico, this species flies for most of the year, but mainly  from June to October. The queens have been collected as early as February in Mexico (Vergara pers. comm.).

Bumble bees, as a whole, are eusocial insects that live in colonies composed of a queen, workers and reproductives (males and new queens). Colonies are annual and only the new, mated queens overwinter. These queens emerge from hibernation in the early spring and immediately start foraging for pollen and nectar and begin to search for a nest site. Nests are often located underground in abandoned rodent nests, or above ground in tufts of grass, old bird nests, rock piles, or cavities in dead trees. Initially, the queen does all of the foraging and care for the colony until the first workers emerge and assist with these duties. Bumble bees collect both nectar and pollen of the plants that they pollinate. In general, bumble bees forage from a diversity of plants, although bumble bee species in a given area can vary greatly in their plant preferences, largely due to differences in tongue length. Bumble bees are well-known to engage in “buzz pollination,” a very effective foraging technique in which they sonicate the flowers to vibrate the pollen loose from the anthers.
population:
We evaluated this species’ spatial distribution over time using a measure of change in the extent of occurrence (EOO; see Figure 2 in the Supplementary Material) and a measure of change in persistence (analytical methods described in Hatfield et al. 2014). We also assessed changes in the species’ relative abundance
(see Figure 1 in the Supplementary Material), which we consider to be an index of abundance relevant to the taxon, as specified by the IUCN Red List Categories and Criteria (IUCN 2012). For all three calculations we divided the database into historical (1805-2001, N=128,572) and current (2002-2012, N=74,682) records. This timeframe was chosen to meet the IUCN criteria stipulation that species decline must have been observed over the longer of three generations or 10 years. Average decline for this species was calculated by averaging the change in abundance, persistence, and EOO. This analysis yielded the following results (see also the graph of relative abundance and map of change in EOO over time in the Supplementary Material):
  • Current range size relative to historic range: 92.49%
  • Persistence in current range relative to historic occupancy: 60.98%
  • Current relative abundance relative to historic values: 70.51%
  • Average decline: 25.34%
EOO losses above are generally in well sampled areas, thus we have a high confidence in the range contraction of 7.51% in the last 10 years. Relative abundance over this time period is declining, but the trend over a longer period of time is essentially flat. Overall, the declines appear relatively low and do not raise concerns at this point.

Note that this analysis did not consider the Mexican distribution of this species, however, the Mexican data is not expected to significantly impact the above results. Of the 459 records in the Mexican bumble bee database (including ECOSUR and other collections), 386 of these are from the recent decade (2002-2012) and the remaining 73 are from prior years (R. Vandame pers. comm. 2014). To our knowledge, declines or range-loss of this species in Mexico have not been documented. However, the distribution restricted on the volcanoes acting as biogeographical islands, along the Trans-Mexican Volcanic Belt, implies the existence of subpopulations of relatively limited extension.

For a graph and map of relative abundance and range changes of this species over time see the Supplementary Material.
range:
This species occurs in the Mountain West east of the Sierra Nevada and in the Rocky Mountains, adjacent southern Canada, and in the Great Plains of the northern United States and southern Canada. Records extend from coastal California, east to Western Minnesota, and south to southern Arizona, New Mexico, and Mexico (Williams et al. 2014). It occurs less commonly in Mexico, where it is restricted to the Central Mexican Plateau (Altiplano Mexicano), a large arid-to-semiarid plateau that extends from the U.S. border south to the Trans-Mexican Volcanic Belt (Labougle 1990). Known records of this species in Mexico are from the following states: Chihuahua, Coahuila, Jalisco, México, Morelos, Nuevo León, Puebla, Querétaro, Tamaulipas, Tlaxcala and Veracruz (ECOSUR database 2014). In addition, Labougle (1990) reports this species from Michoacán. The vertical distribution in Mexico is above 2,300 m asl in the north of the country (ECOSUR database, 2014), and from 3,000-4,300 m asl across the across the trans-Mexican volcanic belt (Labougle 1990). On the Volcanic Belt, the species is restricted to the high volcanoes, which act as biogeographic islands, so that the subpopulations are strictly isolated by distances from 50-100 km. This species and B. rufocinctus are the only Bombus found above 4,000 m asl in Mexico and Central America (Labougle 1990).  

Questionable/Erroneous Records: Several records shown on Discover Life (2014) are considered in error, including records from Wisconsin, Michigan, Alabama, Kansas, and northeastern Minnesota (R. Thorp pers. comm. 2014). None of these records are treated in Williams et al. (2014), nor the analysis supporting this IUCN assessment (Hatfield et al. 2014).

For a graph and map of relative abundance and range changes of this species over time see the Supplementary Material.
useTrade: This species is currently being developed/bred for use as a commercial pollinator.
conservationActions:
The Mexican subpopulations of this species are in need of further surveys, status review, and possibly conservation attention (see Threats section) (R. Vandame pers. comm. 2014). It is recommended that any use of this species as a commercial pollinator in Mexico be restricted to subpopulations that are bred locally from local stock, rather than imported from the United States and Canada (R. Vandame pers. comm. 2014).

In the United States and Canada, specific conservation and research needs for this species have not been identified. Due to the inherent vulnerability of many bumble bee species and importance of supporting wild bee populations for pollination services, the following general conservation practices are recommended: 

  1. Restore, create and preserve natural high-quality habitats to include suitable forage, nesting and overwintering sites. 
  2. Restrict pesticide use on or near suitable habitat, particularly while treated plants are in flower.
  3. Promote farming practices that increase of nitrogen-fixing fallow (legumes) and other pollinator-friendly plants along field margins.  
  4. Minimize exposure of wild bees to diseases transferred from managed bees. 
  5. Avoid honey bee introduction to high-quality native bee habitat.
Additional research needs for North American bumble bees (as a whole) are summarized in Cameron et al. (2011), the final report for the 2010 North American Bumble Bee Species Conservation Planning Workshop.

habitat:
Bombus intrudens is a cuckoo bee, a term used for a specialized lineage of bumble bees (subgenus Psithyrus) that has lost the ability to collect pollen and to rear their brood. As such, these bees do not found their own nests, but instead, usurp the colonies and worker forces of other bumble bee species. To do this, a mated female enters the nest of another bumble bee species, kills or subdues the queen of that colony, and forcibly (using pheromones and/or physical attacks) "enslaves" the workers of that colony to feed her and her developing young. Since all of the resulting cuckoo bee offspring are reproductive (not workers), they leave the colony to mate, and the mated females seek out other nests to attack. Males of this species patrol circuits in search of mates. Before finding and invading a host colony, females feed directly from flowers. The adult food plants of this species include Aster, Cirsium, Echinacea, Helianthus and Solidago (Williams et al. 2014).

Cuckoo bees often attack a broad range of host species, but some specialize in attacking the members of just one species or subgenus. Bombus variabilis (=intrudens) is recorded as breeding as a parasite of colonies of Bombus pensylvanicus (Williams et al. 2014): females usurp established colonies and lay eggs which the workers of the host colony then rear to adulthood. Its host species is associated with open fields and grasslands (Colla and Dumesh 2010).
population:
Several North American studies have found decline in the relative abundance and distribution of this species over time.
