For example, in a study of 56 sites across Illinois, comparisons between recent (2007) surveys and historic records (beginning in 1900) found that although B. variabilis (=intrudens) historically occurred in all geographic regions of the state, it was completely absent in recent surveys and museum collections (2000-2007) (Grixti et al. 2009). This species was last recorded in Illinois in 1980, and is now considered extirpated from the state (Grixti et al. 2009). A larger study considering over 69,000 bumblebee specimens collected from 1865-2010 from various institutions assessed changes in relative abundance and occupancy of 21 North American species and ranked their conservation status throughout their entire U.S. and Canadian ranges (Colla et al. 2012). Although this study considered a larger scale than previous studies, the species found to be declining range-wide were generally consistent with those found to be declining in regional studies. Of all North American bumblebees examined, B. variabilis (=intrudens) was found to exhibit the most decline, showing severe decline in both persistence and relative abundance. This species completely absent from all samples in the most recent time period (1991–2009), despite 94 historical records (Colla et al. 2012).

We evaluated this species’ spatial distribution over time across its North American range using a measure of change in the extent of occurrence (EOO) and a measure of change in persistence (analytical methods described in Hatfield et al. 2014). We also assessed changes in the species’ relative abundance, which we consider to be an index of abundance relevant to the taxon, as specified by the IUCN Red List Categories and Criteria (IUCN 2012). For all three calculations we divided the database into historical (1805-2001, N=128,572) and current (2002-2012, N=74,682) records. This time frame was chosen to meet the IUCN criteria stipulation that species decline must have been observed over the longer of three generations or 10 years. Average decline for this species was calculated by averaging the change in abundance, persistence, and EOO. We used these measures of change between the recent and historic time periods to estimate the population trend that has occurred in the past 10 years, and to inform the application of an IUCN category. This analysis yielded the following results (see also the Supporting Information for Figure 1 - map of change in EOO over time; and Figure 2 - relative abundance trend):
  • Current range size relative to historic range: 42.91%   
  • Persistence in current range relative to historic occupancy: 0.00%*    
  • Current relative abundance relative to historic values: 0.00%*
  • Average decline: 79.71%*
There are no records of this species in North America in the last decade. Our analysis suggests that this species has declined in relative abundance consistently since the 1920s, making it one of the rarest in its range, and possibly extinct (Hatfield et al. 2014) throughout its range north of Mexico. The range size calculation reflects the difference in sampling effort between the historical, and the current sampling period, and recognizes that the lack of recent records may be a artefact of sampling.

*The persistence and relative abundance measures do not reflect the population in Mexico and Central America. However, since the majority of this species' range occurs north of Mexico, and the range loss estimate is very conservative (before correcting for sampling bias, the range loss for this species is greater than 99%), we are still confident that this species meets the quantitative threshold for a Critically Endangered status.
range:
In North America, this species is found in the Eastern Temperate Forest and Great Plains region of the midwestern U.S., with scattered occurrences on the southeastern coastal plain, southern Texas, and southern Arizona (Williams et al. 2014).

Bombus intrudens also occurs in Central America, including Mexico and Guatemala (Williams et al. 2014). The ECOSUR database (2015) includes 133 recent (2009-2013) records of this species, mainly from Guatemala and southeast Mexico (Chiapas state), and few records from other Mexican states (Guerrero, Jalisco, Oaxaca and Veracruz). In addition, there are 21 Mexican records of this species from a number of collections with unavailable record information (Vandame, R. 2014, pers. comm).
useTrade: This species is not used.
conservationActions:
Actions should focus on conservation management of host species in North America as captive rearing of this species is likely not an option. Due to the lack of recent specimens across this species' large range, targeted surveys to locate extant populations are priority for this species. If located, any extant populations should be protected from habitat loss, pesticide exposure and pathogen spillover.

Specific conservation and research needs for this species have not been identified. Research needs for North American bumble bees (as a whole) are summarized in Cameron et al. (2011), the final report for the 2010 North American Bumble Bee Species Conservation Planning Workshop.

habitat:
In Labougle and Ayala (1985), the climate of the collection localities is described as "temperate highland tropical with dry winters" (Cwb in Köeppen classification), and the vegetation is described as Abies forests sometimes mixed with pines and deciduous forest elements.

In Guatemala it has been collected in humid mountain forests, most commonly pine-oak forests, above 2,000 m asl. It is rarely found in open areas that usually are close to mountain forest patches.
population:
Ecosur (El Colegio de la Frontera Sur) compiled a database of 26,211 bumblebee records to assess the status and extinction risk of the Mesoamerican Bombus sp. fauna. To our knowledge there are no recent studies of bumblebee decline in Mesoamerica, including Mexico and Central American countries. Our database consists of 12,210 records of what we consider historic data (1867-2004), obtained from insect collections in the Americas and Europe. The database also contains 14,001 recent bumblebee records (2005-2014), mainly obtained through collaborative sampling efforts conducted by the University San Carlos in Guatemala and El Colegio de la Frontera Sur in Mexico.

We evaluated the spatial distribution of  B. macgregori over time across its Mesoamerican range using a measure of change in the extent of occurrence (EOO) and measure of persistence (analytical methods described in Hatfield et al. 2014). We also assessed changes in the species’ relative abundance, which we consider to be an index of abundance relevant to the taxon, as specified by the IUCN Red List Categories and Criteria (IUCN 2012). For all calculations we divided the database into historical (1867-2004, N =30 and current (2005-2014, N = 77) records. This time-frame was chosen to meet the IUCN criteria stipulation that species decline must have been observed over the longer of three generations or 10 years. Average decline for this species was calculated by averaging the change in abundance, persistence, and EOO. We used these measures of change between the recent and historic time periods to estimate the population trend that has occurred in the past 10 years, and applied that trend to IUCN Criteria. This analysis yielded the following results:

  • Current range size relative to historic range: 35.6%    
  • Persistence in current range relative to historic occupancy: 201.57%
  • Current relative abundance relative to historic values: 220.93%
  • Average decline: 0.0%

Observations:
It is rare in most geographic sites, usually just one or few individuals are collected during a single sampling event. In Guatemala, its potential distribution has been identified as Mountain Forests, although very few collections have been recorded (Vasquez et al. 2010).
There are no known population studies for this species.
range:
This species has been found in the Sierra Madre del Sur, in the Mexican states of Jalisco, Oaxaca, Guerrero and Chiapas. In Guatemala the species has been also collected in the Sierra Madre, in the departments (geographic entities) of San Marcos, Quetzaltenango, Sololá, Chimaltenango, Sacatepequez, Baja Verapaz and Escuintla.

In the last ten years the geographic range of the species has diminished evidently, even when a larger sampling effort has been done and a larger amount of specimens have been collected. The species' elevation distribution (1250-3260 m asl), and the extent of occurrence (14,370.5 km2) were estimated from 106 records from the Ecosur and CECON collections.
conservationActions:
No current actions aimed toward the species conservation are in place.  
Future actions should be aimed towards developing research on ecology, reproductive biology, habitat status evaluations, population monitoring and taxonomy. Also, education programs aimed to local farmers and agro-industry would be strategic in the conservation of the species habitat. The conservation status of this species should be used as an example of the importance of the implementation of international legislation for habitat conservation, and to justify the investment of effort and resources in the protection of the forest remains that supply the habitat requirements of this species. Both the education programs and legal action should highlight the importance of pesticide regulations, forest management and appropriate land use planning.
Also, education programs aimed at all academic levels should promote the knowledge of rare and endemic species like B. macregori. The implementation of local-scale programs that include the conservation, creation, and restoration of potential habitats and floral resource sources (such as rural gardens and field margins) is also recommended. This will not only benefit this species, but all pollinators and floral visitors.

habitat: The distributional pattern in México corresponds with the Bosque Tropical Caducifolio and Bosque Tropical Perenifolio of Rzedowski (1978). In Guatemala the species has been found in tropical lowland rain forests (Selva Tropical Lluviosa) and mountainous tropical forests (Selva de Montaña) (Vasquez et al. 2010). In southern México, specimens can be seen from March to December and more frequently from June to September. The species is believed to be perennial, mostly based on its similarity to B. atratus and the production of relatively large and populated nests (Labougle 1990).
population:
Ecosur (El Colegio de la Frontera Sur) compiled a database of 26,211 bumblebee records to assess the status and extinction risk of the Mesoamerican Bombus sp. fauna. To our knowledge there are no recent studies of bumblebee decline in Mesoamerica, including Mexico and Central American countries. Our database consists of 12,210 records of what we consider historic data (1867-2004), obtained from insect collections in the Americas and Europe. The database also contains 14,001 recent bumble bee records (2005-2014), mainly obtained through collaborative sampling efforts conducted by the University San Carlos in Guatemala and El Colegio de la Frontera Sur in Mexico.

We evaluated the spatial distribution of  B. medius over time across its Mesoamerican range using a measure of change in the extent of occurrence (EOO) (analytical methods described in Hatfield et al. 2014). We also assessed changes in the species’ relative abundance, which we consider to be an index of abundance relevant to the taxon, as specified by the IUCN Red List Categories and Criteria (IUCN 2012). For all calculations we divided the database into historical (1867-2004, N = 1,079) and current (2005-2014, N = 822) records. This time-frame was chosen to meet the IUCN criteria stipulation that species decline must have been observed over the longer of three generations or 10 years. Average decline for this species was calculated by averaging the change in abundance, persistence, and EOO. We used these measures of change between the recent and historic time periods to estimate the population trend that has occurred in the past 10 years, and applied that trend to IUCN Criteria. This analysis yielded the following results:

  • Current range size relative to historic range: 14.13%    
  • Persistence in current range relative to historic occupancy: 65.45%
  • Current relative abundance relative to historic values: 66.29%
  • Average decline: 51.38%


Observations:

In Mexico and Guatemala it is considered a scarce species. In Guatemala the species has been collected in the Petén and Alta Verapaz areas (at approx. 730 m asl) where relatively large remnants of natural forest exist, but there are no recent records from the southern lowlands (Vasquez et. al 2010), where most lands have been used for intensive agriculture. In the rest of the region only bibliographic data is available and there are no reports of field work. Populations within non-intensive agricultural land are believed to be stable.

Extensive systematic surveys for this, and other bumblebee species in the coastal lowlands of western Guatemala, an area from which there exist at least one historic record, were conducted during 2010 and 2011. Sugar cane plantations dominate the landscape in this part of the country, and despite historic records for many different species of bumblebees, not a single Bombus specimen was encountered (N. Escobedo-Kenefic pers. obs. 2011).
range:
This species occurs on the Gulf side and southern México (Sonora, Durango, Tamaulipas, Jalisco, Michoacán, Veracruz, San Luis Potosí, Hidalgo, Distrito Federal, Morelos, Nayarit, Puebla, Guerrero, Oaxaca, Tabasco, Chiapas, Campeche, Yucatán and Quintana Roo), Guatemala (Huehuetenango, Alta Verapaz, Baja Verapaz and Petén), El Salvador (San Salvador), Nicaragua (Matagalpa) to Honduras (Francisco Morazán, Tegucigalpa, Sigualtepeque, Yoro and Zamorano), including the Yucatán Peninsula and there are two records of this species from Panama. Its altitudinal distribution generally ranges from sea level to 1,100 m asl (Labougle 1990), however there are two records at 2200 m asl. for the city of México (Ecosur). In Guatemala it is current in Lower Montane Rain Forest  (1,000-1,800 m asl) and Montane Cloud Forest (1,800-2,500 m asl).  Collections from the Peten area in Guatemala at 730 m asl have been also reported (Vasquez et al. 2010).  Its extent of occurrence has been estimated as 155,633.9 km2, with 1901 records from a data set compiled by Ecosur.

Observations: There are two records in Selva El Ocote Biosfere reserve, in México. The species has also been recorded from the Corredor biológico Chichinautzin. In Guatemala the species has been recently recorded in areas with natural forest remnants and Protection Areas, such as the Petén an Alta Verapaz departments, but not in the southern lowlands that are mostly used for intensive agriculture (Vásquez et al. 2010).
useTrade: There is no use of this species.
conservationActions: For the conservation of this species, we recommend the protection and restoration of native flora including primary forests and secondary growth, in order to provide Bombus medius a suitable nesting habitat. The recommended measures may include changes in agricultural practices to preserve the nests on the ground, controlled practice fire management and good stewardship and sustainable insecticides (Ayala et al. 1996). The encouragement of initiatives for the conservation, creation, and restoration of potential habitats and floral resource sources (such as rural gardens and field margins) is also recommended. This will not only benefit this species, but all pollinators and floral visitors.

habitat: This species is associated with humid Andean forests. In Colombia, the species prefers areas with high humidity in warm to mesothermical climate (Liévano and Ospina 1984). It has been recorded from disturbed land (Nates Parra 2006). Records indicate that workers occur from December to January and that males are on the wing about mid-January at the places where they have been recorded.
population: It is considered an uncommon species, naturally rare probably, mostly collected from protected areas and forests (Rasmussen pers. comm 2012). This species is considered rare in Colombia because its presence in collections is very scarce (Nates Parra 2006). There is no current information on population trends, size, or geographic distribution.
range: This species' distribution ranges from Bolivia northward to Costa Rica and eastward into Venezuela, within an altitudinal range between 1,524 and 2,743 m asl. In Ecuador, an specimen was recorded from San Mateo. In Bolivia, it has been reported from La Paz (Coroico and Yugas). In Costa Rica, it is known from Cartago (Pacays), Puntarenas (Ojuras de Terraba) and San Jose (San Jose). In Panama, a specimen was reported from Chiriqui (El Volcan). In Peru, it was reported from Huanuco (Ambo), Piura (Huancabamba), San Martin (Ayña Forest and Oparo Forest), Apurimac, Ayacucho, Cusco, Pasco, Junin, and Tumbes. In Venezuela, it was found in Territorio de Amazonas (Mount Cerro Duida Region) (Millirion 1973, Rasmussen 2003).
useTrade: This species is not used.
conservationActions: It is probably present in some protected areas (although these forests are often threatened). Occurrence records should be compared with land-use and areas of conservation. There are no species specific conservation measures in place.

habitat: Naturally this species pollinates flowers of Guava Psidium guajaba (Mirtaceae), and coffee Coffea arabica (Rubiaceae). They are believed to fly throughout the year, quite probably at low altitudes in moist montane and lowland tropical forest. It has also been recorded in plantations.
population:
Ecosur (El Colegio de la Frontera Sur) compiled a database of 26,211 bumblebee records to assess the status and extinction risk of the Mesoamerican Bombus sp. fauna. To our knowledge there are no recent studies of bumblebee decline in Mesoamerica, including Mexico and Central American countries. Our database consists of 12,210 records of what we consider historic data (1867-2004), obtained from insect collections in the Americas and Europe. The database also contains 14,001 recent bumble bee records (2005-2014), mainly obtained through collaborative sampling efforts conducted by the University San Carlos in Guatemala and El Colegio de la Frontera Sur in Mexico.

We evaluated B. mexicanus’ spatial distribution over time across its Mesoamerican range using a measure of change in the extent of occurrence (EOO) and a measure of change in persistence (analytical methods described in Hatfield et al. 2014). We also assessed changes in the species’ relative abundance, which we consider to be an index of abundance relevant to the taxon, as specified by the IUCN Red List Categories and Criteria (IUCN 2012). For all calculations we divided the database into historical (1867-2004, N = 627) and current (2005-2014, N=118) records. This time-frame was chosen to meet the IUCN criteria stipulation that species decline must have been observed over the longer of three generations or 10 years. Average decline for this species was calculated by averaging the change in abundance, persistence, and EOO. We used these measures of change between the recent and historic time periods to estimate the population trend that has occurred in the past 10 years, and applied that trend to IUCN Criteria. This analysis yielded the following results:

  • Current range size relative to historic range: 16.71%    
  • Persistence in current range relative to historic occupancy: 67.19%
  • Current relative abundance relative to historic values: 16.41%
  • Average decline: 66.71%
range: This species has been reported from the Eje Volcanico Transversal in Central Mexico south to Guatemala, El Salvador, Honduras, Nicaragua, Costa Rica and Panama. It is known from Guatemala (Chimaltenango, Escuintla, Guatemala, Quetzaltenango,  Retalhuleu, Sacatepequez, San Cristobal, San Marcos, Solola and Suchitepequez), El Salvador (La Libertad, La Paz, Morazan and San Salvador), Honduras (Choluteca and Francisco Morazan), Nicaragua (Carazo, Jinotega, Managua and Rivas), Costa Rica (Cartago, Guanacaste, Heredia, Puerto Limon, Puntarenas and San Jose), Panama (Chiriqui), Colombia (Bogota) and Ecuador (Abrahamovich et al. 2004, Labougle 1990). The distribution in Colombia and Ecuador reported by Franklin (1913) couldn't be verified with specimens found in those countries. In Mexico, the distributional pattern corresponds in part to the Bosque Tropical Caducifolio and Bosque de Pino y Encino of Rzedowski (1978). Milliron (1973a) recorded one specimen (worker) from El Destierro, San Luis Potosí, well north of the area from where other specimens were found by Sasal (pers. obs. 2012). The global altitudinal range for this species ranges from 150 m up to 2700 m, being more frequent at 400-1000 m. A few of the many specimens recorded from Costa Rica and a specimen labelled Balboa, Panama, (if the locality is correct) were captured at sea level (Labougle 1990).
useTrade: There is no use of this species.
conservationActions: It is not known if this species is present in protected areas. No species specific conservation measures are in place.

habitat:
In contrast to most bumble bee species inhabiting temperate regions which have one generation per year, evidence from Brazil indicates that B. morio may have at least two generations per year and is active throughout the year (Camilo and Garófalo 1989), which can also be true for other tropical regions.

Bombus morio, as most bumblebees, is polylectic; it has been reported to visit flowers from 34 plant species from 14 different families in Argentina, with the largest number of visited plant species belong to Asteraceae, Fabaceae and Solanaceae, and to a lesser extent species of Lammiaceae, Bromeliaceae, Cannaceae, Convolvulaceae, Cucurbitaceae, Lythraceae, Piperaceae, Pontederiaceae, Rubiaceae, Tiliaceae and Verbenaceae (Abrahamovich et al. 2001). In Brazil, Camillo and Garofalo (1989) reported this species visiting 29 plants species in a single site, collecting pollen and nectar from two plant species, collecting only nectar from 17 and only pollen from other 10 species.
population: According to Abrahamovich and Diaz (2001) and Rasmussen (2003) this species is particularly common  and widespread in Brazil and Argentina. There is no published survey on the species population trend or status.
range:
Species of widespread distribution in Tropical and Subtropical South America, in particular in Argentina and Brazil. Its southern limit is ca. 33° latitude South. It has been cited for the following countries (number of subcountry units between brackets): Brazil (13), Argentina (10), Bolivia (6), Colombia (1), Ecuador(2), Paraguay (9), Peru (3), Uruguay (1) and Venezuela (1) (Abrahamovich and Diaz 2002). However, it has been recorded only in one location in each of the two later countries (Abrahamovich and Díaz 2002, Abrahamovich et al. 2004). This species is more common in north Argentina and Brazil than in the remaining countries of occurrence (Rasmussen 2003).

According to citations, its range almost completely overlap with B. atratus, with the exception of Guayanas, northern Brazil and Chile, where B. morio is absent (Milliron 1973a).

In Argentina B. morio has been recorded (i.e. at least one pinned specimen exists) in all the administrative provinces of north and centre-north Argentina, including Catamarca, Chaco, Corrientes, Formosa, Jujuy, Misiones, Salta, Santa Fe, Santiago del Estero and Tucumán,  with more frequency of localities in the Salta and Tucuman (Abrahamovich and Diaz 2001). This species has also been cited for the provinces of Córdoba and Buenos Aires, in the centre and centre-east of Argentina, respectively. However, data of specimens revised from the former are equivocal and no record exists for Buenos Aires, despite intensive sampling (Abrahamovich and Diaz 2001), thus presence in these provinces is uncertain.

In Perú has been only cited for the Valley of Huallaga (Huaunco) (Rasmussen 2003).

The historic extent of occurrence (if Colombia and Uruguay are taken in account) includes almost all South American countries, with the exception of Chile and the Guyanas (see map). However, the Amazonian and Orinoco Basins seem to be areas unsuitable for the species, probably because these are too humid (annual rain >2,000 mm).

This species has been reported within an altitudinal range between 0 and 2,380 m. asl.
conservationActions: According to its widespread distribution, this species may be present in many protected areas of the countries of occurrence.

habitat:
Bombus nevadensis inhabits open grassy prairies and meadows. Nesting occurs underground, and less often on the surface. Males perch and chase moving objects in search of mates. This species is classified as a long-tongued species, whose food plants include Astragalus, Cirsium, Melilotus, Monarda, Penstemon, Phacelia, Salvia, Stachys, Trifolium and Vaccinium. (Williams et al. 2014).

Bumble bees are social insects that live in colonies composed of a queen, workers and reproductives (males and new queens). Colonies are annual and only the new, mated queens overwinter. These queens emerge from hibernation in the early spring and immediately start foraging for pollen and nectar and begin to search for a nest site. Nests are often located underground in abandoned rodent nests, or above ground in tufts of grass, old bird nests, rock piles, or cavities in dead trees. Initially, the queen does all of the foraging and care for the colony until the first workers emerge and assist with these duties. Bumble bees collect both nectar and pollen of the plants that they pollinate. In general, bumble bees forage from a diversity of plants, although individual species can vary greatly in their plant preferences, largely due to differences in tongue length. Bumble bees are well-known to engage in “buzz pollination,” a very effective foraging technique in which they sonicate the flowers to vibrate the pollen loose from the anthers. Tomatoes (Solanaceae), blueberries (Ericaceae), and many other important food plants are pollinated by bumble bees in this way.
population:
Williams et al. (2014) describe this species as moderately common. 

We evaluated this species’ spatial distribution over time using a measure of change in the extent of occurrence (EOO; see Figure 2 in the Supplementary Material) and a measure of change in persistence (analytical methods described in Hatfield et al. 2014). We also assessed changes in the species’ relative abundance (see Figure 1 in the Supplementary Material), which we consider to be an index of abundance relevant to the taxon, as specified by the IUCN Red List Categories and Criteria (IUCN 2012). For all three calculations we divided the database into historical (1805-2001, N=128,572) and current (2002-2012, N=74,682) records. This timeframe was chosen to meet the IUCN criteria stipulation that species decline must have been observed over the longer of three generations or 10 years. Average decline for this species was calculated by averaging the change in abundance, persistence, and EOO. This analysis yielded the following results (see also the Supplementary Material for a graph of relative abundance and map of change in EOO over time): 
  • Current range size relative to historic range: 104.71%
  • Persistence in current range relative to historic occupancy: 84.78%
  • Current relative abundance relative to historic values: 64.08%
  • Average decline:  15.48%
This analysis suggests that although relative abundance has declined somewhat, there have not been significant declines in range or persistence over the last ten years.  

Note that this analysis did not consider the Mexican distribution of this species, however, since this species is known from a very small number of records in Mexico (Williams 2014, ECOSUR 2014), the Mexican data would not have significantly impacted the above results.

For a graph and map of relative abundance and range changes of this species over time, see the Supplementary Material.
range:
This species occurs in the Mountain West from southern Arizona and New Mexico north to British Columbia and the Yukon. It also occurs in the highlands of the Desert West, southern California Transverse Ranges, Sierra-Cascade Ranges, and sparingly in the Coast Ranges, east to the western Great Plains. This species is not included in the Bumble Bees of Mexico report by Labougle (1990), but Milliron (1971) reports a single queen of this species from Hidalgo, Mexico (coll. 1961), and the ECOSUR database of Mexican records lists an additional four specimens from from Puebla, Mexico (coll. 1991) (R. Vandame pers. comm. 2014). Note, however, that the identification of the Mexican specimens is uncertain; recent examination of the five Mexican specimens by Philippe Sagot suggests that these specimens are likely to be Bombus auricomus rather than B. nevadensis (P. Sagot pers. comm 2014, R. Vandame pers. comm. 2014). Genetic analysis of these specimens (or others from the region) is needed before conclusions can be drawn (P. Williams pers. comm. 2014). 

Distribution is from sea level up to 2,200 m asl in the United States and Canada, and up to 2,741 m asl in Mexico.

Questionable/Erroneous Records: Discover Life (2014) shows a number of apparently erroneous records including those from eastern North America, Japan and Chile.

For a graph and map of relative abundance and range changes of this species over time, see the Supplementary Material.
conservationActions:
Conservation Needed: Specific conservation needs for this species have not been identified. Due to the inherent vulnerability of many bumble bee species and importance of supporting wild bee populations for pollination services, the following general conservation practices are recommended:
  • Restore, create and preserve natural high-quality habitats to include suitable forage, nesting and overwintering sites. 
  • Restrict pesticide use on or near suitable habitat, particularly while treated plants are in flower.
  • Promote farming practices that increase of nitrogen-fixing fallow (legumes) and other pollinator-friendly plants along field margins. 
  • Minimize exposure of wild bees to diseases transferred from managed bees. 
  • Avoid honey bee introduction to high-quality native bee habitat.
Research Needed:   Genetic analysis of specimens from Mexico is needed, in order to obtain more evidence for the species' taxonomy and phylogeny in this region (P. Williams pers. comm. 2014). Since the five known specimens are over 20 years old, collection of new material for genetic barcoding should be prioritized.

Additional research needs for North American bumble bees (as a whole) are summarized in Cameron et al. (2011), the final report for the 2010 North American Bumble Bee Species Conservation Planning Workshop.

habitat: Apparently a common species in the Alti-plano region of southern Peru and Bolivia. In Peru only observed at close to 4,000 m asl, an altitude generally of few bees - although these specimens likely need to be re-examined (PH Williams, pers. comm. 2016). Agriculture at this altitude is often interspersed with natural vegetation but the bees seem to forage and thrive also within agricultural fields (Rasmussen pers. comm. 2012). Joergensen (1909) and Abrahamovich et al. (2001) cite this species in Argentina as having been captured on the flowers of Baccharis (Baccharis pingraea, Baccharis salicifolia, Baccharis serrulata), Caesalpinia, Cirsium (Cirsium lanceolatzim), Cucurbitella, Cyanara (Cynara cardunculzis), Delphinium, Dipsacus, Eupatorium (Eupatorium hookerianurn),  Hualamia, Hyalis (Hyalis argenterr), Lippia, Luzerne, Lycium, Marrubium, Priva, Proustia (Proustia ilicifolin), Salvia, Senecio (Senecio mendocinus, Senecio natus and Senecio subulatus), Taraxacum (Taraxacum oficinale) and Verbena (Ximenesia microptera = Verbesina encelioides) (Asteraceae), Cucurbitella scaberrima (= Cucumis anguria) (Cucurbitaceae) (Rasmussen 2003, Milliron 1973).
population: This appears to be common in suitable habitat (pers. obs. in Altiplano of Puno, Peru, C. Rasmussen). However, little information is known about the abundance trends.
range: The type locality is Mendoza, Argentina. It has been recorded from Paraguay, northern Argentina and Chile, northward to Ecuador. In Argentina, it has been reported from Catamarca (El Cavillo, Hualfin (Los Nacimientos-Aquas Termanles) and Los Angeles), Cordoba (La Falda, Cordoba, Huerta Grande, La Cocha, Mercedes (San Luis), Ojo de Agua, Punilla and Villa Hermosa), Jujuy (La Esperanza, Las Capillas, Volcan, Carmen (La Sala Cerro del), Guerrero, Humahuaca, La Quiaca, Los Perales and Malpaso), Mendoza (Pedregal, Santa Rosa, Cachueta, Potrerillos and Upsallata), La Rioja (Los Sauces), Salta (Cafayate, Cerro San Bernardo, San Carlos, Angariaco, Molinos and San Lorenzo), Tucuman (Abra de la Quenoz, Cainzo (Quebrada), Departamento Trancas (San Pedro de Colalao) Amaicha del Valle, Siambon (Tafi). In Bolivia, specimens have been recorded from Cochabamba (Aquirre, Chapare, Cochabamba, Cristal (Mayu Chapare) and Incachaca) and La Paz (La Paz, Lago de Titicaca and Puerto Acosta). In Paraguay, it has been recorded from Caraguatay (Caraguatay) and Guayra (Colonia Carlos Pfannel). In Peru, it has been recorded from Cajamarca (Chimo and La Huerta), Camacani, Arquetipa, Tacna and Puno. In Chile, it is known from Coquimbo (Las Vacas). In Ecuador, workers and males have been found in Esmeraldas (Ambato) (Milliron 1973, Rasmussen 2002).
useTrade: This species is not used.
conservationActions: It is not known if the species is present in any protected areas. Occurrence records should be compared with land-use and areas of conservation. There are no specific conservation measures in place.

habitat:
Bumblebees, as a whole, are eusocial insects that live in colonies composed of a queen, workers, and reproductives (males and new queens). Colonies are annual and only the new, mated queens overwinter. These queens emerge from hibernation in the early spring and immediately start foraging for pollen and nectar and begin to search for a nest site. Nests are often located underground in abandoned rodent nests, or above ground in tufts of grass, old bird nests, rock piles, or cavities in dead trees. Initially, the queen does all of the foraging and care for the colony until the first workers emerge and assist with these duties. Bumblebees collect both nectar and pollen of the plants that they pollinate. In general, bumblebees forage from a diversity of plants, although bumblebee species in a given area can vary greatly in their plant preferences, largely due to differences in tongue length. Bumblebees are well-known to engage in “buzz pollination,” a very effective foraging technique in which they sonicate the flowers to vibrate the pollen loose from the anthers.

Bombus pensylvanicus is found in open farmland and fields throughout its range (Williams et al. 2014), although it was common in urban areas in central Midwest (MO, KS, AR, IL, etc.) during the 1980s and early 1990s (S. Cameron and J. Lozior pers.comms. 2012). It nests mostly on the surface of the ground, among long grass, but occasionally underground (Williams et al. 2014). It is one of the more aggressive bumblebee species, probably as an adaptation to protect the more exposed aboveground nests (Williams et al. 2014).  Males congregate outside nest entrances in search of mates (Williams et al. 2014). Example food plants include Astragalus, Cirsium, Cornus, Dalea, Echinacea, Helianthus, Kallstoemia, Liatris, Mentzelia, Silphium, Solanum, Trifolium, and Vicia. This species is host to Bombus variabilis (Williams et al. 2014).
population:
Recent DNA barcodes support that Bombus sonorus is conspecific with B. pensylvanicus (Williams et al. 2014). A population from the south of Mexico (state of Chiapas) is morphologically and genetically distinct from the rest of North America, and could be a separate undescribed species. Further sampling is needed to clarify the situation.

Historically, Bombus pensylvanicus was among the broadest ranging bumblebees in North America (Cameron et al. 2011). However, numerous studies indicate that this species has recently declined, both locally and regionally, especially in the northern parts of its range. For example, a study examining changes in bumblebee community composition throughout Illinois found that although B. pensylvanicus comprised 28.1% of all bumblebees sampled between 1900 and 1949, it represented only 4.4% of the relative abundance in collections from 1950-2007, including extensive surveys performed at 56 sites across the state in 2007. In addition to abundance declines, this study found B. pensylvanicus has exhibited significant range declines in Illinois, and is no longer found in the northern 1/3 of the state (Grixti et al. 2009). In New York State, Giles and Ascher (2006) failed to find this species in a survey of 1200 bumblebees in the Black Rock Forest, despite evidence it was historically common in the region. In a study in Guelph, Ontario, a comparison of relative abundances of bumblebees collected from 1971-1973 and from 2004-2006 found B. pensylvanicus to be completely absent in surveys from 2004-2006, despite previously having a relative abundance of almost 5% in similar surveys carried out in the same region from 1971-1973 (Colla and Packer 2008).

Looking more broadly, a recent long-term study examining historical changes in 187 species of bees (both Bombus and non-Bombus) in the northeastern United States found that B. pensylvanicus, along with two other Bombus species, has exhibited statistically significant, rapid, and recent population collapse across its northeastern U.S. range (Bartomeus et al. 2013). Similarly, in another study comparing current and historical distributions of eight bumblebee species in the United States using nationwide survey data and museum records, Cameron et al. (2011) found that the relative abundances of B. pensylvanicus has sharply declined in recent years, from >45% to ~10% relative abundance in the Global East, and from >20% to <5% in the Northern/Coastal East, in comparison with the co-distributed B. impatiens, B. bimaculatus, B. terricola, and B. affinis (see Figure 2 in Cameron et al. 2011). In this study, intensive survey efforts of >16,000 bees in 40 states (2007-2009) failed to find this species across large parts of its historical northern and eastern range, resulting in a 23% range reduction of this species in the recent time period (Cameron et al. 2011). It remains common in parts of its range, largely in the southern Midwest and the southern U.S., especially Texas, Oklahoma, Missouri, and Alabama, although comparisons of survey data with museum collections of multiple species suggest that its relative abundance has declined in recent years in these regions (Cameron et al. 2011). In another comprehensive study of bumblebee decline across both the United States and Canada, Colla et al. (2012) found B. pensylvanicus to be one of the most declining species of the 21 species examined, persisting in only 34% of re-sampled historically occupied 50 x 50 km grid cells throughout its United States and Canada range (Colla et al. 2012). This study highlights B. pensylvanicus as one of the most sharply declining species in North America (Colla et al. 2012).

We evaluated this species’ spatial distribution over time in North America (north of Mexico) using a measure of change in the extent of occurrence (EOO) and a measure of change in persistence (analytical methods described in Hatfield et al. 2014) (Figure 1 in the Supplementary Material). We also assessed changes in the species’ relative abundance (Figure 2 in the Supplementary Material), which we consider to be an index of abundance relevant to the taxon, as specified by the IUCN Red List Categories and Criteria (IUCN 2012). For all three calculations we divided the database into historical (1805-2001, N=128,572) and current (2002-2012, N=74,682) records. This timeframe was chosen to meet the IUCN criteria stipulation that species decline must have been observed over the longer of three generations or 10 years. Average decline for this species was calculated by averaging the change in abundance, persistence, and EOO. This analysis yielded the following results (see Supplementary Material for map of change in EOO over time (Figure 1) and graph of change in relative abundance (Figure 2)):

  • Current range size relative to historic range: 81.18%
  • Persistence in current range relative to historic occupancy: 53.24%
  • Current relative abundance relative to historic values: 11.44%
  • Average decline: 51.38% 


The analysis indicates a decline in both distribution and relative abundance in North America, north of Mexico. The decline in EOO is most severe in northern areas, which have been well sampled, although the species may have been historically uncommon in the northern part of its range. Its relative abundance trend has been slowly moving downward until recently when the downward trend has become much sharper (but is not statistically significant).

Mexican summary:  The ECOSUR database (2015) includes 599 recent (2012-2013) records of this species from numerous Mexican states (Aguascalientes, Baja California, Baja California Sur, Chiapas, Chihuahua, Coahuila, Distrito Federal, Durango, Guanajuato, Guerrero, Hidalgo, Jalisco, México, Michoacán, Nayarit, Nuevo León, Oaxaca, Puebla, Querétaro, San Luis Potosí, Sinaloa, Sonora, Tamaulipas, Tlaxcala, Veracruz, Zacatecas). In addition, there are 2127 Mexican records of this species from a number of collections with unavailable record information (R. Vandame pers. comm. 2014).
range: Bombus pensylvanicus is widespread in the Eastern Temperate Forest and Great Plains regions throughout the eastern and central U.S. and extreme southern Canada, absent from much of the Mountain West, but found in the Desert West and adjacent areas of California and Oregon (Williams et al. 2014). This species also occurs in Mexico, where it is known from the following states: Aguascalientes, Baja California, Baja California Sur, Chiapas, Chihuahua, Coahuila, Distrito Federal, Durango, Guanajuato, Guerrero, Hidalgo, Jalisco, México, Michoacán, Nayarit, Nuevo León, Oaxaca, Puebla, Querétaro, San Luis Potosí, Sinaloa, Sonora, Tamaulipas, Tlaxcala, Veracruz, and Zacatecas (ECOSUR Database 2015).
useTrade: No trade for this taxon
conservationActions:
A 120-year long study in Illinois found this species to be the most connected pollinator species in the region and its decline resulted in loss of ecosystem function (Burkle et al. 2013).  Therefore conservation actions are important and may include:

  • Determining the effects of pathogens on populations of B. pensylvanicus and if possible eradication efforts should be implemented.
  • Restoration, protection and creation of natural grassland habitat throughout its range
  • Avoiding the use of pesticides adjacent to forage, overwintering and nesting habitat.
  • Promoting the use of nitrogen-fixing fallow in farming management plans. 


Any conservation actions that benefit B. pensylvanicus will also benefit B. variabilis, which is a social parasite of this species (Williams et al. 2014), and has also experienced dramatic population declines (Grixti et al. 2009; Hatfield et al. 2014).

Additional specific conservation and research needs for this species have not been identified. Research needs for North American bumblebees (as a whole) are summarized in Cameron et al. (2011b), the final report for the 2010 North American Bumble Bee Species Conservation Planning Workshop.


More details on the population trends and status of this species in Mexico are needed.

habitat:
In Central America it is probably found in the Bosque de Niebla, and in equivalent vegetation in South America; in the lowlands it should be found in Bosque Tropical Perennifolio (Janzen 1971, Labougle 1990). The seasonal distribution is probably all year long. In Colombia, it is found marginally in el Piso Montano, between 2,800 and 3,800 m asl. (Nates Parra 2006).

B. pullatus inhabits the hot, moist conditions of tropical rain forest (Hines et al. 2007, Cameron and Williams 2003).

There are descriptions of its nest occurring both arboreally (Janzen 1971) and at ground level, particularly associated with the ant Acromyrmex octospinosus (Chavarria 1996).

The first described B. pullatus nest was found in the leaves of a living banana tree in the lowlands of Costa Rica (Janzen 1971). The nest was constructed of a thin vegetative mache, which sealed and closed off the nest, and had a broad entrance on one side. Chavarria (1996) found four active nests in Costa Rica located on the surface of the ground, but only described one of them. It was situated among the roots of a coffee plant and contained old, empty bee brood cells in use by fungus ants.

The nest described by Hines et al. (2007) was a large conical mound of cut vegetation on the ground apparently constructed by the bees, and was found in grassy substrates in secondary forest or disturbed areas. All described B. pullatus nests (Janzen, 1971, Chavarria 1996, Hines et al. 2007) were built around tree roots, shrubs, leaves, or saplings, which probably anchor nests and shield them from tropical rainstorms.

Bombus pullatus forms large colonies with signs of perenniality (Janzen 1971, Chavarria 1996, Hines et al. 2007). The colony described by Janzen (1971) contained 343 adults and 160 immature bees, and that described by Chavarria (1996) contained 500 adults. The B. pullatus nest described by Hines et al. (2007), with 414 workers and 533 immature bees, was larger than most temperate colonies. The colonies were very aggressive (Janzen 1971, Chavarria 1996). Foragers were polylectic and foraging activity was highest in the morning (Hines et al. 2007).
population:
Ecosur (El Colegio de la Frontera Sur) compiled a database of 26,211 bumblebee records to assess the status and extinction risk of the Mesoamerican Bombus sp. fauna. To our knowledge there are no recent studies of bumblebee decline in Mesoamerica, including Mexico and Central American countries. Our database consists of 12,210 records of what we consider historic data (1867-2004), obtained from insect collections in the Americas and Europe. The database also contains 14,001 recent bumblebee records (2005-2014), mainly obtained through collaborative sampling efforts conducted by the University San Carlos in Guatemala and El Colegio de la Frontera Sur in Mexico.

We evaluated B. pullatus’ spatial distribution over time across its Mesoamerican range using a measure of change in the extent of occurrence (EOO) and a measure of change in persistence (analytical methods described in Hatfield et al. 2014). We also assessed changes in the species’ relative abundance, which we consider to be an index of abundance relevant to the taxon, as specified by the IUCN Red List Categories and Criteria (IUCN 2012). For both calculations we divided the database into historical (1867-2004, N = 1344) and current (2005-2014, N=129) records. This time-frame was chosen to meet the IUCN criteria stipulation that species decline must have been observed over the longer of three generations or 10 years. Average decline for this species was calculated by averaging the change in abundance, persistence, and EOO. We used these measures of change between the recent and historic time periods to estimate the population trend that has occurred in the past 10 years, and applied that trend to IUCN Criteria. This analysis yielded the following results:

  • Current range size relative to historic range: 85.66%
  • Persistence in current range relative to historic occupancy: 136.20%
  • Current relative abundance relative to historic values: 8.37%
  • Average decline: 0.00%

The average decline is actually 23.26%, however, considering the undersampling in Costa Rica (see Red List rationale), the change in relative abundance is not considered, so that the average decline is negative, which actually indicates that this species in increasing in abundance, and therefore the average decline is considered to be 0%.

Because the status of this species in countries south of Mesoamerica is uncertain (see Distribution section), the figures above are an incomplete picture of this species' overall status. Additional research in museum collections and efforts to survey for this species in countries in northwestern South America are critical to understanding its historic and current distribution throughout the region.
range:
Bombus pullatus is distributed from the south of Mexico to Central America, limited to Panama. It is abundant in the tropical lowlands of Central America, but also occurs at higher elevations (Hines et al. 2007). The altitudinal distribution is from sea level to 3355 m, but the species is more frequently collected above 1000 m (Janzen 1971, Labougle 1990). 

Cross mis-identifications with B. atratus Franklin (1913) are common in many collections, and molecular analyses are required to separate clearly the two species. While B. atratus absence in Central America is almost certain, it is probable that B. pullatus is present in northwestern countries of South America. However, this requires more work to get certainty. For this reason, we consider only B. pullatus from Mexico to Panama in this assessment, and ignore South American data. However, the status of this species in South American is critical to its conservation status, and thus we will list this species as Data Deficient.
useTrade: There is no use of this species.
conservationActions: It is not known if populations can be found within protected areas. There do not appear to be any species specific conservation measures in place.

habitat: It is only known from grasslands in north Peru but extends northward and is supposedly common in Colombia. According to Milliron (1973), queens or workers or males, or combinations thereof, might be recorded any time of the years at the appropriate place in the species´range.
population: This species appears to be naturally rare. Little is known about the species population trends or current distribution.
range: Bombus robustus is found in northern South America, recorded in Peru (Rasmussen 2003), Colombia (Nates-Parra 2006), Venezuela and Ecuador down to the Azuay Province (Frison 1925, Milliron 1937b). It ranges from 762  to 3,800 m asl. (in Colombia Montane floors) (Milliron 1973, Rasmussen pers. comm. 2012). According to Milliron (1973), in Colombia, the species has been recorded from Cundinimarca (Bogota, Paramo de Guerrero and Obonuco), Putumayo (Putumayo River), Magdalena (Las Nubes, Onaca, Sierra San Lorenzo and Valparaiso), Meta (Villavicencio), Narino (Pasto), Vaupes and Guarnaque. In Ecuador, it has been found from Manabi (Limon), Oriente (Santa Rosa), Pichincha (Quito), Azuay (Cumbe) and Tungurahua (Ambato and Monte de Tungurahua). In Venezuela, it has been reported from La Culata and Apartaderos, both in Merida.  Rasmussen (2002) reports this species in Peru only from Cajamarca. There is an incorrect record of a queen from Jujuy Argentina and an additional record of a worker from Bolivia that is uncertain (Milliron 1973).
useTrade: This species is not used.
conservationActions: It is not known if the species is present in any protected areas. Occurrence records should be compared with land-use and areas of conservation. No species specific conservation measures are in place.

habitat: The habitat of this species does not appear to have been recorded. Bombus rohweri may be more abundant than B. funebris at higher altitudes even if geographical overlapping could be shown to occur (Mayr 1969, Van Asperen de Boer 1993).
population: This is a very localized and scarce species. Little is known about the population trends or current distribution for this species.
range: The type locality is Valera, Venezuela. Its distribution ranges from Colombia and Venezuela, at an altitudinal range between 2,377 and 4,100 m. asl. (Milliron 1973, Van Asperen de Boer 1993). In Venezuela, it has been reported from Mérida (Apartaderos,  Frailes and Sierra Nevada) and Valera (Milliron 1973, Van Asperen de Boer 1993, Rasmussen pers comm. 2013). In Colombia it was recorded in Cundinamarca (Bogota). In Peru, it was recorded from Ancash (Huaraz) (Milliron 1973) and from Ollantaytambo (Van Asperen de Boer 1993). Rasmussen never collected this species in Peru (pers comm. 2013). Records from Peru and perhaps Ecuador are considered to be in error (Rasmussen pers comm. 2013).
useTrade: This species is not used.
conservationActions: It is not known if the species occurs in any protected areas. Occurrence records should be compared with land-use and areas of conservation. There are no specific conservation measures in place. Further research is needed into the range, habitat and population status of this scarce and little-known species.

habitat: According to Milliron (1973), it may be found at any time of the year at the appropriate location in the species' range. In Peru this species is limited to the more humid parts of the Andes between 2,000-3,000 m asl. (Rasmussen pers. comm. 2012).
population: This species is known to be relatively common in suitable habitat in Colombia, and apparently rare elsewhere (Rasmussen pers. comm. 2013). There appears to be little information on the population trends or current distribution for this species.
range: The type locality is Colombia. It is known from Bolivia northward to Venezuela. There is one queen labelled as from Honduras that is considered doubtful by Milliron (1973). In Bolivia, it was recorded from Cochabamba (Cochabamba and Locotal) and Cordillera. In Colombia, this species has been reported from Bolivar (Volcan de Galeras), Boyaca (Mongui and Tunja), Cundinamarca (Bogota, Guasca and Paramo Guerrero) and Nariño (Pasto, Montaño Paramo). In this country, it is typically Andine, found in Piso Montano, between 2,800 and 3,800 m asl. In Ecuador, it has been found  in Azuay (Cumbe), Tungurahua (Monte Tungurahua) Pundoa, and Pichincha (Quito). In Peru, it is known from Ancash (Tomeque) and Cajamarca (Collanga). In Venezuela, specimens have been recorded from Merida (La Culata) and Territorio de Amazonas (Sierra).
useTrade: This species is not used.
conservationActions: It is not known if this species occurs in any protected areas. Occurrence records should be compared with land-use and areas of conservation. There are no species specific conservation measures in place.

habitat: No information is available on its habitat and ecology.
population: No information is available about its population but it is likely to be extinct (Williams 2014). It is not known if there have been any recent dedicated surveys to look for this species.
range: This bumblebee has only been reported from the type specimen probably collected in Brazil (Millirion 1973, Williams 2014). However, the species is not listed for Brazil (Moure and Sakagami 1962, Abramovich and Díaz 2002). It has been reported as extinct by Williams (1998, 2014), Abramovich and Diaz (2002) and Williams and Osbourne (2009). In a recent and thorough study of the unique specimen of this species ever known, and of the label indicating locality, Williams (2014) confirmed that from available information this species is likely to be extinct. Moreover, he concluded that indirect evidence from morphology and the historical biogeography of bumblebees supports a South American type locality, with the Brazilian Atlantic Forest as a likely candidate.
useTrade: There is no use of this species.
conservationActions: Research work to determine if the species is still extant is recommended.

habitat:
This species is short-tongued and small bodied. It is found commonly close to or within wooded areas, urban parks and gardens (Williams et al. 2014). Example food plants include Chicorium, Eupatorium, Fragaria, Grindelia, Helianthus, Melilotus, Solidago, Trifolium, Vicia and Viguiera. It usually nests on the surface or above ground. Males perch and chase moving objects in search of mates (Williams et al. 2014). 

Bumble bees, as a whole, are eusocial insects that live in colonies composed of a queen, workers and reproductives (males and new queens). Colonies are annual and only the new, mated queens overwinter. These queens emerge from hibernation in the early spring and immediately start foraging for pollen and nectar and begin to search for a nest site. Nests are often located underground in abandoned rodent nests, or above ground in tufts of grass, old bird nests, rock piles, or cavities in dead trees. Initially, the queen does all of the foraging and care for the colony until the first workers emerge and assist with these duties. Bumble bees collect both nectar and pollen of the plants that they pollinate. In general, bumble bees forage from a diversity of plants, although bumble bee species in a given area can vary greatly in their plant preferences, largely due to differences in tongue length. Bumble bees are well-known to engage in “buzz pollination,” a very effective foraging technique in which they sonicate the flowers to vibrate the pollen loose from the anthers.
population:
Populations of this bee appear to be stable in most of its range, and may even be increasing in some areas. In a study in Illinois, 2007 surveys of 57 sites across the state revealed B. rufocinctus in all geographic regions in which it was previously recorded, based on museum specimens from 1900 and onward (Grixti et al. 2009). In another regional study in southern Ontario, Colla and Packer (2008) found this species had over two times greater relative abundance in 2004-2006 than was exhibited during surveys at these same sites a few decades earlier (1971-1973). Range-wide, this species also appears to be stable. In a large study considering over 69,000 bumblebee specimens representing 21 species collected from 1865-2010 in eastern North America, Colla et al. (2012) assessed changes in relative abundance and occupancy of this species and ranked its conservation status throughout the entire United States and Canadian range. This study found B. rufocinctus persisted in 67% of re-sampled historically occupied 50 x 50 km grid cells throughout its United States and Canada range, and significantly increased in relative abundance over the time periods examined. Williams et al. (2014) describe this species as widespread and common throughout its range, but note that it had disappeared from the San Francisco Bay Area by 2002, an area where it was historically uncommon (McFrederick and Lebuhn 2006). 

The population of this species in central Mexico is apparently isolated from the United States populations, and with very few (21) records, its status is not well-known. Surveys in this region from 2012 to 2014 were unable to detect this species (R. Vandame pers. comm. 2014).  

We evaluated this species’ spatial distribution over time using a measure of change in the extent of occurrence (EOO; see Figure 2 in the Supplementary Material) and a measure of change in persistence (analytical methods described in Hatfield et al. 2014). We also assessed changes in the species’ relative abundance (see Figure 1 in the Supplementary Material), which we consider to be an index of abundance relevant to the taxon, as specified by the IUCN Red List Categories and Criteria (IUCN 2012). For all three calculations we divided the database into historical (1805-2001, N=128,572) and current (2002-2012, N=74,682) records. This timeframe was chosen to meet the IUCN criteria stipulation that species decline must have been observed over the longer of three generations or 10 years. Average decline for this species was calculated by averaging the change in abundance, persistence, and EOO. This analysis yielded the following results (see also the graph of relative abundance and map of change in EOO over time in the Supplementary Material): 
  • Current range size relative to historic range: 91.45%
  • Persistence in current range relative to historic occupancy: 106.47%
  • Current relative abundance relative to historic values: 154.88%
  • Average decline: 0.00%
These results suggest that range-wide declines, either in relative abundance or range, are not a cause for concern for this species. This aligns with a number of recent studies demonstrating that this species is stable or even increasing throughout the eastern and central portions of its range (Colla and Packer 2008, Grixti et al. 2009, Colla et al. 2012). 

For a graph and map of relative abundance and range changes of this species over time see the Supplementary Material.
range:
This widespread species occurs in the Canadian Maritimes and Eastern Temperate Forest and Boreal Forest regions, from New Foundland west through the north and central Great Plains, Mountain West, and also the Pacific Coast in California, with isolated records from Alaska (Williams et al. 2014). It also occurs rarely in Mexico, where it is limited in distribution to the Trans-Mexican Volcanic Belt (Eje Volcánico Transversal), a volcanic belt that extends from west to east across central-southern Mexico (Labougle 1990). Known Mexican localities are from (1) the State of Mexico (Estado de México): Toluca and Santa Elena-Toluca; (2) the Federal District (Distrito Federal); (3) the Volcán, Popocatépetl (Labougle 1990); and (4) the states of Tlaxcala and Hidalgo (R. Vandame pers. comm. 2014). There are 21 records for this species in the current database of Mexican bumble bee records (ECOSUR 2014, including holdings from ECOSUR and other collections).

For a graph and map of relative abundance and range changes of this species over time see the Supplementary Material.
useTrade: There is no trade or commercial use of this taxon.
conservationActions:
Conservation Needs: Specific conservation needs for this species have not been identified. Due to the inherent vulnerability of many bumble bee species and importance of supporting wild bee populations for pollination services, the following general conservation practices are recommended: 

  1. Restore, create and preserve natural high-quality habitats to include suitable forage, nesting and overwintering sites. 
  2. Restrict pesticide use on or near suitable habitat, particularly while treated plants are in flower.
  3. Promote farming practices that increase of nitrogen-fixing fallow (legumes) and other pollinator-friendly plants along field margins.  
  4. Minimize exposure of wild bees to diseases transferred from managed bees. 
  5. Avoid honey bee introduction to high-quality native bee habitat.

Research Needs:  In addition, the northern area of this species' range is undersampled (Hatfield et al. 2014). Further surveys of this species are needed in Mexico, where the status and population trends are not well-known (R. Vandame pers. comm. 2014). Additional research needs for North American bumble bees (as a whole) are summarized in Cameron et al. (2011), the final report for the 2010 North American Bumble Bee Species Conservation Planning Workshop.

habitat: It can be found in pine-oak forest, thorn forest, and tropical dry forest (Rezedowski 1978). Specimens of both sexes and the two female castes can be found in every month of the year.
population:
Ecosur (El Colegio de la Frontera Sur) compiled a database of 26,211 bumblebee records to assess the status and extinction risk of the Mesoamerican Bombus sp. fauna. To our knowledge there are no recent studies of bumblebee decline in Mesoamerica, including Mexico and Central American countries. Our database consists of 12,210 records of what we consider historic data (1867-2004), obtained from insect collections in the Americas and Europe. The database also contains 14,001 recent bumble bee records (2005-2014), mainly obtained through collaborative sampling efforts conducted by the University San Carlos in Guatemala and El Colegio de la Frontera Sur in Mexico.

We evaluated B. steindachneri’s spatial distribution over time across its Mesoamerican range using a measure of change in the extent of occurrence (EOO) and a measure of change in persistence (analytical methods described in Hatfield et al. 2014). We also assessed changes in the species’ relative abundance, which we consider to be an index of abundance relevant to the taxon, as specified by the IUCN Red List Categories and Criteria (IUCN 2012). For all calculations we divided the database into historical (1867-2004, N =791) and current (2005-2014, N=49) records. This time-frame was chosen to meet the IUCN criteria stipulation that species decline must have been observed over the longer of three generations or 10 years. We used these measures of change between the recent and historic time periods to estimate the population trend that has occurred in the past 10 years, and applied that trend to IUCN Criteria. This analysis yielded the following results:

  • Current range size relative to historic range: 13.98%    
  • Persistence in current range relative to historic occupancy: 41.99%
  • Current relative abundance relative to historic values: 5.40%
  • Average decline: 79.54%
range: This species is native to Mexico, where it is known from the Eje Volcanico transversal, Sierra Madre Occidental, and Sierra Madre del Sur of Mexico. It has been recorded from Chihuahua, Sonora, Durango, Sinaloa, Nayarit, Jalisco, Michoacán, Estado de México, Morelos, Puebla, Guerrero and Oaxaca. The altitudinal distribution in the Pacific Coast (Jalisco, Nayarit, Sinaloa and Sonora) ranges from sea level to 2,600 m asl, and in the central part of México from 1,000 to 1,900 m asl. Labougle (1990) suggested the presence at lower altitudes in the Rio Balsas.
useTrade: There is no use of this species.
conservationActions: There is a need to protect the native flora, for instance creating habitat along field margins to benefit bumblebees and other pollinators, and to protect the habitat for species nesting below ground. The proposed measures may include changes in agricultural practices to preserve the nests on the ground, controlled fire management practices and good stewardship and sustainable use of insecticides (Ayala et al. 1996).

habitat:
A survey of nine colonies of this taxon yielded a maximum size of 400 adults and over 600 immatures (Taylor and Cameron 2003). Tropical bumblebee colonies tend to be larger than temperate colonies, with the largest recorded colony belonging to B. transversalis (3,056 individuals, including adults and brood) described by Dias (1958) in Brazil. According to Taylor and Cameron (2003), B. transversalis nests are conical or dome-like in shape, with a structure that consists primarily of small fragments of cut leaves, giving the impression of a pile of thatched debris. Nests are constructed on terra firme, on the surface of the ground and incorporate elements of growing vegetation as physical support, consisting of a thatched canopy of tightly woven leaves and rootlets, beneath which lies the brood and food storage pots which are dry inside, despite torrential rainfall and external relative humidity levels near 100%. Also, they observed that to build the nest, workers cut and transport leaves from the surrounding forest floor. In addition, Hines et al. (2007) pointed out that all observed nests were cryptic and hard to distinguish from the surrounding ground litter and live vegetation.

Nest architecture of this species also appears to be modified for life in tropical lowland forests. Bumble bees usually establish nests in pre-existing cavities, either underground or beneath dead vegetation. Workers cut and gather leaf litter, which they fashion into conical surface nests. They cut vegetation with their mandibles and move it toward the nest by sweeping it backward under the legs in groups of several bees doing, sometimes in tandem, what forces the cut vegetation onto the mound, where it is incorporated into the thatched nest cover. This action results in the clearing of vegetation in the vicinity of the nest and provides the bees with a dense, waterproof canopy (Cameron and Whitfield 1996, Cameron et al. 1999, Taylor and Cameron 2003). The nest canopy also acts as a first-line impediment to attack by predatory raids of army ants (Eciton) as they scour the forest floor in search of small prey (Ramírez and Cameron 2003).

The nests have been more commonly observed in leaf litter substrates of primary rainforest. In several nests (Cameron et al. 1999, Taylor and Cameron 2003), construction and maintenance involved cutting vegetation on top of or around the nest with the mandibles and moving these pieces using the mandibles or a backwards directed sweeping behaviour of the mid and hind legs.

B. transversalis colony development in the Amazon Basin is synchronized with the seasonal wet/dry cycles: colonies are established during the wet season and complete their reproductive cycle during the dry season. Observations on colony cycle, in combination with a number of our observations of nest age and structure, suggest that colonies (adults and brood cells) of this species may be seasonal, while the nest structure itself (no adults and brood) may be perennial (Olesen 1989). Local inhabitants at several study sites claimed to have seen B. transversalis nests persisting for several years (Taylor and Cameron 2003).

Related to the social behaviour of B. transversalis, Cameron et al. (1999) observed that this species presents extreme aggression in its foraging activity (Sakagami et al. 1967, Olesen 1989, Cameron et al. 1999), which is highest in the morning. Also, workers clean and maintain trials on the ground near the nest (Cameron and Whitfield 1996, Cameron et al. 1999).

Liévano and Ospina (1984) pointed out that this species, typically found in the Amazon region, has also been recorded in areas of extensive livestock and agriculture.
population: There is no recorded information on population trends, size, or geographic range. However, this species is known to be abundant, has a broad range, and there are no reports of species decline or specific identified threats.
range: Bombus transversalis is distributed from northern South America to central Bolivia (Abrahamovich et al. 2004). It exist in tropical lowland rain forest and it is found only in the Amazonian Basin (Olesen, 1989, Rasmusen, 2003). It is known from Bolivia (Cochabamba, El Beni, La Paz and Santa Cruz), Brazil (Acre, Amapa, Amazonas, Matto Grosso, Para and Rodonia), Colombia (Amazonas and Distrito Capital), Peru (Amazonas, Huanuco, Junin, Loreto, Madre de Dios, Pasco and Ucayali), Ecuador (Quito), French Guiana (Saint-Laurent-du-Maroni), Guyana, Suirname (Marowijne) and Venezuela (Bolivar) (Rasmusen 2003, Abramovich et al. 2004, and Moure and Melo 2012).
useTrade: This species is not used.
conservationActions: It is not known if populations are present within protected areas. No species specific conservation measures are in place.

habitat: This species is strongly related to pine-oak forests in mountains, both in Mexico and Guatemala, and also very restricted to the mountains of Mexico (Guerrero, Oaxaca, Veracruz) and Guatemala (San Marcos, Huehuetenango, Sololá and Quetzaltenango).
population:
Ecosur (El Colegio de la Frontera Sur) compiled a database of 26,126 bumblebee records to assess the status and extinction risk of the Mesoamerican Bombus sp. fauna. To our knowledge there are no recent studies of bumblebee decline in Mesoamerica, including Mexico and Central American countries. Our database consists of 12,210 records of what we consider historic data (1867-2004), obtained from insect collections in the Americas and Europe. The database also contains 13,916 recent bumblebee records (2005-2014), mainly obtained through collaborative sampling efforts conducted by the University San Carlos in Guatemala and El Colegio de la Frontera Sur in Mexico.

We evaluated B. trinominatus’ spatial distribution over time across its Mesoamerican range using a measure of change in the extent of occurrence (EOO) (analytical methods described in Hatfield et al. 2014). We also assessed changes in the species’ relative abundance, which we consider to be an index of abundance relevant to the taxon, as specified by the IUCN Red List Categories and Criteria (IUCN 2012). For both calculations we divided the database into historical (1867-2004, N = 135) and current (2005-2014, N= 539) records. This time-frame was chosen to meet the IUCN criteria stipulation that species decline must have been observed over the longer of three generations or 10 years. We used these measures of change between the recent and historic time periods to estimate the population trend that has occurred in the past 10 years, and applied that trend to IUCN Criteria. This analysis yielded the following results:

  • Current range size relative to historic range: 134.84%    
  • Persistence in current range relative to historic occupancy: 645.03%
  • Current relative abundance relative to historic values: 361.11%
  • Average decline: 0.0%
range:
B. trinominatus is usually found in mountains of Oaxaca, Guerrero, Veracruz, and Tlaxcala in Mexico. In Guatemala it can be found in Los Cuchumatanes, Huehuetenango, and the volcanoes of Tacaná and Tajumulco in San Marcos. It has also been cited to occur in the mountains near Quetzaltenango and Sololá in Guatemala, but recently this area is under heavy pressure changing forests into corn crop fields. 

This species is found at altitudes above 2,572 m asl (lowest data recorded in Mexico) up to 3,500 m asl (highest data recorded in Guatemala). This was estimated with 694 records from a data set compiled by Ecosur and CECON.
useTrade: This species is not used.
conservationActions: There is little information on this species or its ecology. We strongly recommend the preservation of pine-oak forests and the habitat related to it for the continued success of this species. In Guatemala, it present in the areas that are protected by the SIGAP (Sistema de Areas Protegidas) of Guatemala.

habitat: Bombus tucumanus is associated with four plant species of the families Bignoniaceae, Fabaceae, Lamiaceae and Solanaceae (Abrahamovich et al. 2001a). It has been recorded from habitats of prepuna (shrubland), puna (grassland) and yugas (forest).
population: Bombus tucumanus is one of the least abundant species of Argentina (Abrahamovich 2001a,b) and it is also naturally rare within the Bolivian Puna, Prepuna and Yungas biogeographic provinces. There is little information about the population trend for this species, or the current geographical distribution.
range: Bombus tucumanus is present in south-western Bolivia and north-western Argentina (Abramovich et al. 2004). It is found in the Andean region, with a wide vertical tolerance, reaching 4,000 m asl. In Bolivia, it is known from the Cochabamba and La Paz provinces, and in Argentina from Catamarca, Jujuy, Salta and Tucuman (Abramovich et al. 2004, Moure and Melo (2012). It is found from 300 to close to 4,000 m asl.
useTrade: This species is not used.
conservationActions: There is no information about conservation measures in place. It may be present in Parque Nacional El Rey and Parque Nacional Calilegua in Argentina.

habitat: In Colombia, the species prefers areas with high humidity in warm to mesothermical climate (Liévano and Ospina 1984). It has been recorded from disturbed land (Nates Parra 2006).
population: This is a naturally rare species. There is little information available on the population trends or current distribution for this species.
range: The type locality for the species is Huancabamba, Piura in Peru. It ranges from Bolivia northward to Colombia (and likely eastward into Venezuela). A record from Argentina (one males from San Pedro de Colalao in Tucuman) needs confirmation.  Its altitudinal range goes between 914 to 2,017 m. asl. Due to confusion with B. melaleucus some reports may be incorrect (Milliron 1973). In Bolivia, specimens have been reported from Chapare and Cochabamba (Tarata), La Paz (Coroico, Yugas del Palmar, Yugas de la Paz and Chulumani). In Peru, it is known from Ancash (Pillahuata), Cusco (Macchu Picchu), Huanuco (Ambo, Omgu, Huanuco), Junin (Valle de Chanchamayo), San Martin (Ayna Forest and Opara Forest),  Cajamarca (Callanga), Piura (Pilco, Huancabamba), and San Miguel. In Colombia, it is known from an indeterminate locality in Monte Redondo. In Ecuador, it has been reported from Oriente (Baños) and Pandoa (Milliron 1973).
useTrade: This species is not used.
conservationActions: It is not known whether the species occurs in any protected areas. Occurrence records should be compared with land-use and areas of conservation. There are no specific conservation measures in place.

habitat: It can be found in pine forest and oak forest, and tropical dry forest (Rezedowski 1978),  but also in dry areas like Sierra de Juarez in Oaxaca during the wet season, July and August.
population:
Ecosur (El Colegio de la Frontera Sur) compiled a database of 26,211 bumblebee records to assess the status and extinction risk of the Mesoamerican Bombus sp. fauna. To our knowledge there are no recent studies of bumblebee decline in Mesoamerica, including Mexico and Central American countries. Our database consists of 12,210 records of what we consider historic data (1867-2004), obtained from insect collections in the Americas and Europe. The database also contains 14,001 recent bumble bee records (2005-2014), mainly obtained through collaborative sampling efforts conducted by the University San Carlos in Guatemala and El Colegio de la Frontera Sur in Mexico.

We evaluated B. weisi’s spatial distribution over time across its Mesoamerican range using a measure of change in the EOO (see Figure 1 in the Supplementary Information) and a measure of change in persistence (analytical methods described in Hatfield et al. 2014). We also assessed changes in the species’ relative abundance, which we consider to be an index of abundance relevant to the taxon, as specified by the IUCN Red List Categories and Criteria (IUCN 2012). For all calculations we divided the database into historical (1867-2004, N =293 ) and current (2005-2014, N=1682) records. This time-frame was chosen to meet the IUCN criteria stipulation that species decline must have been observed over the longer of three generations or 10 years. Average decline for this species was calculated by averaging the change in abundance, persistence, and EOO. We used these measures of change between the recent and historic time periods to estimate the population trend that has occurred in the past 10 years, and applied that trend to IUCN Criteria. This analysis yielded the following results:

  • Current range size relative to historic range: 42.69%    
  • Persistence in current range relative to historic occupancy: 373.12%
  • Current relative abundance relative to historic values: 434.53%
  • Average decline: 0%
range: This species is found from Mexico to Costa Rica. In Mexico, it ranges from the Pacific Coast mountains (Sierra Madre Occidental, Sierra Madre del Sur, Sierra Madre de Chiapas) to the Eje Volcánico transversal, southern portion of the Altiplano Mexicano, and Sierra Madre Oriental. It was recorded from Chihuahua, Sinaloa, Durango, Jalisco, Michoacán, Mexico State, Morelos, Distrito Federal, San Luis Potosí, Hidalgo Tlaxcala, Puebla, Veracruz, Guerrero, Oaxaca and Chiapas.
